message+desc: These multicolored decorative paintings on the surface of traditional Korean wooden buildings are called DANCHEONG (Îã®Ï≤≠). The color and pattern can differ according to the class and use of a building. Dancheong paintings use five basic colors based on the Philosophy of the Five Elements: blue for wood and east; red for fire and south; yellow for earth and center; white for metal and west and; black for water and north.
comments:
What's the colour for plastic surgery per chance??$$but why blue for wood  and black for water  ?? kto$$I've read it also represent social status and rank by using various patterns and colors. Koreans are very artistic (y)$$very interesting, that is so cool$$Great architecture and meanings of five elements.$$wow it is a super image from korea it hinkt he korean are the unique in the world to paint in the wood$$Any detail history about it?
Maybe it useful for my education in University$$Any detail history about it?
Maybe it useful for my education in University$$thank you, another history lesson for me and my family$$wow...amazing...can you imagine being the one to paint all of that?$$woah....if we see the building like this...we must look up to see the beautiful and the art of the decoration.....hee....interesting ^^

message+desc:
Secrets of the #Seoul buses! üöåüòÅ (bit.ly/SeoulBuses)
Though #subways are very convenient, #buses are also a great mode of transportation to explore the city! Did you know, the buses in Seoul are classified as follow:
- #Blue Bus: Buses that travel on major roads and run for relatively long distances through Seoul.
- #Green Bus: Buses that travel shorter distances 
- #Red Bus: Rapid buses that travel from Seoul to suburban areas
- #Yellow Bus: Circular route buses, quite rare

Also, the first 2 digits of the bus numbers show their departure & arrival region. For example, Bus No. 7011 departs from 'Eunpyeong' to 'Jung-gu' and thus the number starts with '7' followed by '0'. Like this post if you think it's helpful/interesting! (Y) ^_^

Wow very nice KTrivia...thanks for sharing KTO, now we know and makes me excited to ride a bus again in Seoul ^_^$$Yeah, i finally get it xD thank you very much (Y)$$Is there online info about each bus route?$$Are there any Seoul Bus apps that actually show all the routes overlayed on a map?$$Where can I get a printable (PDF) version of this map?$$Haha I went to Seoul 22 times and never knew about this system. 
This is cool and I am a babo :)$$1st time took bus during my trip in November last year. It was so excited to see the city full of autumn leaves when in the bus. Thanks for share the info. Hope to take bus again during next trip$$Wow! This is useful~ I usually stay at Yongsan and there is a bus stop in front! I shall use this to help me in future! Gomawo~ =)$$I may not understand this for a while, but when I get the chance to have a trip on my own, I know it will be very useful to me. ^^$$This map is really a cheating sheet for Seoul buses - thanks KTO üòÑ$$Been there and our fave is #261 wherever we go we usually see that bus and we took that bus everytime we go home!$$Green 7011, 7013 are passing the front of my region. (Mapo District)$$My life has just been changed.   Thank you!$$I didn't know that! Hahaha! This is very helpful.$$We should keep this in mind üòÑ Charity Lime Jaz$$Myra Tan we usually use the subway. Hehe$$Edlyn Buelva Unnie, we should take note this..$$Was comfortable for me )$$Cool üëçüèº interesting info!$$Wow!! message+desc:
Great spin on a traditional summer treat! Iced Hongsi (persimmon pulp) is usually eaten by scooping it directly out of the persimmon but packaging it like this means that it's easy to store and eat! 100% Persimmon, nothing added. 
Pick some up when you go to Sangju City next time!
comments:
easy to eat? yeah right! mine broke, so i stuck it with a straw and i'm sucking it out of the bottom. „Öã„Öã$$I ate mine in like 5 minutes and had no trouble.  I guess it depends on individual ability.  hehe

Marie$$gosh, i need this right now..its VERY HOT here in Malaysia! $$I imagine!  I was really happy to recieve it today. Wish I could share!$$thanks for sharing the photo tho! haha.. $$Since the only English words you see in Jack Lee's post are both related to digestion, I'll translate what he said.

Persimmon is really good for diarrhea but if you eat too much you can get constipation. In that case it is really painful.  

So the key is, don't eat to many persimmons! Just one a day will be perfect. :)$$I think you have to go to Sangju City to get it, or you can order it off the internet (korean page). Free shipping in Korea, except Jeju (small charge applies)
http://www.sangjumall.co.kr/jsp/shop/itemView.jsp?pcode=336

Photo from zirky33-travel.blogspot.com

message+desc:
Higashiomi Giant Kite Festival will be held in May 26th at Higashiomi Fureai Sports Park, Higashiomi City, Shiga pref. The main attraction is kite-flying which is the largest kite in Japan and has a history of more than 300 years.The size of the kite is 100 tatami mats (about 165 m2) and it requires as many as 100 people to fly it. Members of the public can also join as a kite flyer! Never try kite-flying? Visit the festival and have fun!!
 
Location: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/shiga/
comments: These giant kite-flying events are amazing to watch, especially when several kites are in the air at the same time.$$wow...that's  a hugh a kite

message+desc: Buenos dias, Pilipinas! And before you think we've suddenly turned Spanish, that's actually "Good morning, Philippines" in Chabacano! Zamboanga's local dialect is fused with tons of Spanish words because of its early settlers. Fantastico, isn't it? (Oops, now that's Italian.)

message+desc:
Let‚Äôs take a look into the intricate and complex world of origami, which is so much more than a children‚Äôs pastime.
Over the years Japanese people started enjoying the act of folding paper itself without the formality and rules associated with gift wrapping, resulting in the ‚ÄúOrigami‚Äù we see today. Now Origami is enjoyed all over the world and continues to evolve. 

Learn more: http://japan-magazine.jnto.go.jp/en/1606_origami.html

We found a container night market in JB called Kilang Bateri a short drive from Singapore. There are no crowds on weekdays! It lies about 25 mins from the causeway and sells more than just food. 

We found a traditional barber shop, a vintage shoe shop that sells branded shoes at prices as low as SGD25 and had amazing seafood at only SGD20!

message+desc:
Do you know what this flower is?
This is called "Takane ruby" which is red soba (buckwheat noodle) flower in Minowa Town, Nagano.„ÄÄNormally, the flowers of soba are white in Japan, however the seed of soba with red flowers were brought from the Himalayas and improved.„ÄÄIt's in full bloom from middle of September to early October. Enjoy the flowers and soba at there!!
Destination guide: http://www1.town.minowa.nagano.jp/html/english/minowa_town.html

message+desc:
Have you already enjoyed any summer festivals in Japan?
The Shan-Shan Festival is taking place in Tottori city until August 15th!
About 4000 participants perform the dance using the umbrellas with bells.
The name "Shan-Shan" comes from the sound of the bell.
If you are in Tottori pref., visit there and share your experience!
Destination guide: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/tottori/tottori_city.htm
comments: I lived in Tottori for a year, and it's a delightful place in the countryside near the Japan Sea. Most people walk along and enjoy bits and pieces of the parade during the festival. We sat down on the curb and watched the entire thing!

message+desc:
It's A-Boat Time!

Running on it‚Äôs 5th year, Sea-Expo is a three day boat show and nautical lifestyle event that celebrates the Philippine‚Äôs most valuable natural resource, the ocean. 

It is the only event in the country where the local and international marine industry come together to showcase their products and services to the Philippine market. The goal: to be recognized as a serious market and as a viable sector for development and investments. 

Sea-ex also aims to promote tourism by being a destination event at par with other boat shows held by it‚Äôs
Asian neighbors. 

Visit http://www.facebook.com/philseaexpo for more details.

message+desc:
Welcome to Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium, #Japan

Okinawa's wealth of nature, history and culture can be experienced at Ocean Expo Park, a place where you can even enjoy a dolphin show.

Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium is one of many popular facilities at Ocean Expo Park.

At the Aquarium, an intriguing world of marine life found in Okinawa is spread out before you. A sea of coral dazzled with sunlight exhibits living coral colonies in large scale.
With its enormous capacity, a gigantic tank called The Kuroshio Sea Tank the largest fish in the world, the whale shark, and the world's first successfully bred-in-captivity manta can also be seen. Moreover, you can experience the sea of Okinawa when you journey into the deep sea, which recreates Okinawa's mystery-enshrouded sea.

We hope to see you at Okinawa Churaumi Aquarium, where new encounters and discoveries await each time you visit!

#Share & #Tag anyone you would like to go on a #Vacation with!
#Like our page to explore the world's hidden gems with Tripviss

The collection of photographs features Filipino baroque churches and will be shown around the country as well as in Paris this year. 

In the photo is Mr. Ferranti explaining his shots of the Paoay Church in Ilocos Norte, a UNESCO World Heritage Site. 

Photo from http://www.elysee.fr

message+desc:
Photo of the day is Kappabashi Bridge at Kamikochi, Nagano pref.
The area is known as one of the most scenic spot in Japan, and you could enjoy its rich natural environment! The route to Kamikochi has closed during the winter, but it‚Äôs opened last Saturday! Opening Ceremony at Kappabashi bridge will be held on April 27th. From late May to early June, you could enjoy watching fresh green leaves. From July to August, various flowers bloom beautifully, and from early to late October, you can see beautiful autumn leaves. Make a trip plan in your favorite season!
  
Location details: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/nagano/kamikouchi.html
Photo courtesy: ¬©Matsumoto city¬©JNTO

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Calanggaman Island, Leyte

What is it? 
By those who know about it, this ten-hectare hidden gem is adored for its supremely fine white sands. But the real adventure begins below the surface ‚Äîwith up to 30-meter visibility and an expansive reef, this marine reserve also provides a mystifying dive experience.

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila to Calbayog or Tacloban

Fun Fact: 
The island gets its name from the Cebuano word for bird, possibly owing to the two sandbars that stretch out like wings from its shores.

Photo by/Headline by: 
Jeffrey Bautista / Magnus Ahmad
comments:
It's not a "hidden gem" anymore lol$$I went this island before...really it is so lovely...$$Its more fun in the Philippines!..

Wow.......$$How to get here in palompon, fly to tacloban then rode a van bound to palompon ;)

message+desc:
Where is it?
The Malaca√±ang Palace, Manila

What is it?
Before it became the Presidential Palace, Malaca√±ang Palace was a temporary summer home for Spanish governors and American civil governors.

Fun Fact:
There are several theories as to how the palace got its name. The official story from the 1930s says the name comes from a Filipino phrase which means "there is a nobleman here," because it was originally the home of a wealthy Spanish merchant."

Photo by the Tourism Department of the Philippines.
comments: Not inspiring. Rather embarrassing looking at the pollution and weather stains. You could at least show the front of Malaca√±ang.$$Actually I think it was the official residence of the Captain Generals, not their summer home.

message+desc:
July 7th is a Tanabata Festival (Star Festival) all over Japan.
According to a legend, the two stars, Vega and Altair, separated lovers, are allowed to meet each other across the Milky Way only once a year on the evening of July 7th. The custom is to set up leafed bamboo branches in the garden, and people write poems, words or wishes on tanzaku or long strips of colorful paper which they tie on the bamboo leaves.
comments: Oh so thats where the man I am searching for is??  Across the freaking milky way!!!!   Great.....   This will be interesting trying to date. $$so lovely..festival..meaningful of 7th day of 7th mth..:))

message+desc:
Lavender belongs to a group of herbs that are native to the coastal area of the Mediterranean Sea.
However, they can be seen in Japan! The climate of Furano, Hokkaido allows for a number of lavender fields to spread throughout the region, making it the perfect symbol for the Furano area. 
The flowers are generally in full bloom from mid-June to late July.
Why not visit Furano and be healed by a field of lavender?

Related Information: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/hokkaido/furano.html

message+desc: Who loves bacon? Alam niyo ba that there is a district called Bacon in Sorsogon? It boasts of a handful of beaches, islands and this secluded lagoon called Paguriran. Be a More Fun advocate and share with your friends who like bacon!
comments: What a nice cove... May I know where this is?$$It's in Sorsogon. The lagoon is called Paguriran. :D$$You have to wear water shoes as the jagged/sharp limestone surrounding the lagoon would really hurt your feet. You can either swim from the shore or ride a banca which takes only a few minutes. You may see corals, small fish of different species, some crustacean such as crabs, also seashells attached to the limestone. Some people have a picnic there but unfortunately they leave some of their stuff which ruins the place. I hope this issue has been addressed. Its been a few years since I visited. The lagoon is quite small but very picturesque and on a clear day, you'll see Mayon Volcano in the distance. It's about an hour from Sorsogon City to Bario Sawanga where the lagoon is located just off shore. The road is paved so its quite easy to get there. It's worth a visit!

message+desc:
Where is it?
Callao Cave, Cagayan

What is it?
The mystical Callao Cave is the prize of Cagayan Province, holding seven chambers riddled with stalactites and stalagmites, and illuminated by natural crevices.

How to get there?
Fly into Tuguegarao from Manila. Or take a bus bound for Tuguegarao or Aparri from Manila.   Or take a bus bound for Claveria from Ilocos Norte.

Fun Fact:
The main attraction of the cave is in the first chamber, where the locals have built a functioning chapel.

Photo by/Caption by:
Donie Cruz/Magnus Ahmad

Its more fun ..$$Oh wow really so amizing i like it..i visit that if i hve tym,$$Beautiful caves!!! What an adventure!$$For Booking for you tour in Callao Cave, Visit our website :)    http://www.tuguegaraotravel.com/

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Taal Lake, Batangas

What is it? 
Since 1572, Taal has erupted at least 34 times. The most recent large eruption was on this day back in 1965. Although considered active, this small volcano has been quiet over the last few decades. There are even hiking tours and overnight camping packages on offer now.

How to get there: 
Take a bus to Batangas from Cubao or Pasay.

Fun Fact: 
Want to know what it's like to swim inside a volcano? You can in Crater Lake. It's said that the high sulfuric content has medicinal properties. Some people have even scuba dived here. But don't stay too long. The lake water also has high concentrations of boron, magnesium, aluminum and sodium in salt form.

Photo by/Headline by: 
Roshan Nandwani/Donna Dimayuga
comments: I was there! I miss that view so much!

message+desc:
Photo of the day is Karatsu Kunchi Festival.
The festival will be held from Nov. 2 to 4 every year at Karatsu city, Saga pref. and has a history of 400 years.
14 floats which weight 2 to 4 tons and height is 7 meters parade around old castletown of Karatsu city with shouts of "Enya, enya!"
Visit the festival and let's cheer for them!
  
More details: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/festival/karatsukunchi.html
Official site: http://www.karatsu-kankou.jp/english.html

message+desc:
Where is it?
Intramuros, Manila 

What is it?
Intramuros was once the seat of Spanish-colonial power.  Historical tours and remnants of the country's colorful past can be found here in Old Manila. 

Fun Fact:
Intramuros means "within the walls."  Part of the complex is San Agustin Church -- a UNESCO World Heritage Site.

Photo by George Tapan

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Club Paradise Resort, Palawan

What is it like? 
Club Paradise Resort is surrounded by a house reef which is easily accessible to divers and has a diverse marine system. Near this reef is the feeding ground of sea turtles and dugongs (sea cows) ‚Äì the gentle giants of the sea. There are tours that take you along the coast of Busuanga for some dugong-watching.

Fun Fact: 
Some believe that stories of mermaids came about when lonely sailors spotted dugongs swimming in the ocean, and mistook their shape as that of half-woman, half-fish creatures.

Photo by/Author: 
George Tapan/Tin Sanchez
comments: Mmmm looks sexy and serene$$Can't wait to get there!!!$$kalnggaman bato s palompon leyte.1 of the best ilsand ngyn. s aplompon leyte$$Raquel and I were there........beautiful!$$missing the philippines,its people and its food,cant wait to visit again,

message+desc:
Let‚Äôs take a bath at the oldest spa in Japan in cold winter!

 Dogo-onsen Hot Spring in Ehime prefecture is the oldest spa in Japan. It is said to have 3,000 year history and there is a story that it healed a deity‚Äôs illness in ancient time. The Main Building is a communal bathhouse built in 1894. Take a bath in an old architecture and relax in Japanese ‚Äúyukata‚Äù(a casual summer kimono made of cotton) style wear in a spacious tatami salon or a private room with green tea and sweets.

Ehime Pref.

message+desc:
Madakaripura Waterfall, Probolinggo is a magnificent place that would bring you into a peaceful impression. Located in Bromo Tengger Semeru National Park, it well-known as the biggest waterfall in East Java. The Madakaripura is a set of seven waterfalls, the biggest cascade of which falls from a height of 200 m. The water cascades from the dense forest above. Whilst the bottom part of waterfall is no longer flowing stream of water, it turns into a mist of cold prickly rapid splashes.
 
#WonderfulIndonesia #PesonaIndonesia
comments: Reminds me of the waterfall on Samosir Island, Toba.$$Most beautiful waterfall i've ever seen..üòç

message+desc:
Perhaps the most famous pavilion around West Lake is Jixian Pavilion and for good reason. From here, you can get a picturesque view of West Lake in its entirety. Pavilions are traditionally supposed to be integrated with the surrounding scenery, and this one is no exception. As you walk out along the causeway to the pavilion, it feels as though you are walking on the water itself. 

Behind you, you see the traditional Chinese architecture, while in front, there's nothing but the huge expanse of the lake and its surrounding mountains and pagodas.  Hangzhou, China for more on Hangzhou!  #travel #visitChina
comments: William Jack this is where we are going üòç

message+desc:
Aoi Festival, well known as one of the 3 major annual festivals in Kyoto, will be held on May 15th. Over 500 people wearing traditional clothes, which nobles used to wear in Heian Period (794Ôºç1192), are going to parade all the way from the Kyoto Imperial Palace to the Kamigamo Shrine (About 5 hours).You will be able to see superb traditional costumes as well as make-up. Also, please don't forget to eat Yakimochi (Japanese steamed rice bun stuffed with sweet red bean paste) when you visit the Kamigamo Shrine. It's been loved by local people for long! 
Now are you getting interested in Kyoto?
More info: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/festival/aoimatsuri.html
The parade route: http://www.kyokanko.or.jp/aoi/junkou.html
comments: "Aoi" is not hollyhock. It is "saishin" a woodland plant called wild ginger in the genus Asarum.

Shri Digambar Jain Lal Mandir is the oldest Jain temple in Delhi. Replete with intricate carvings and paintings, the architecture of the temple will leave you stunned. 

The temple complex houses a bookstore where you can find literature and souvenirs on Jainism. #DidYouKnow the temple also hosts a charity hospital for birds. 

#Jainism #Delhi #architecture #IncredibleIndia
comments: The hospital is one of its kind in India and first in world

message+desc:
Naha Giant Tug-of-War (Oo-tsunahiki) Festival will be held from Oct. 11th to 13th in Naha City, Okinawa.
 On the second day, Oct. 12th, you could see Naha Giant Tug-of War on Kokusai Street.
The giant rope is about 186 m or about 203 yards total length and a gross weight of 40t!
150,000 participants pull the rope against each other and it takes usually 20-30 min for victory or defeat.
Let's enjoy the powerful festival in Naha, Okinawa!! 
  
Area Information: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/okinawa/naha.html
NAHA NAVI: http://www.naha-navi.or.jp/index.php
Naha Giant Tug-of-War: http://www.naha-otsunahiki.org/en/index.html

message+desc: Bromo Tengger Semeru Nat. Park, East Java.
comments:
Mount Bromo was one of more accessible volcano' s close to where Pam and I lived in East Java. The Hindu' s had a religious festival there every year and offered prayers and through offerings into the crater. The local Muslims used to risk life and limb by climbing down into the mouth of the volcano gases and all and retrieving as many offerings as they could and selling them to Hindu' s as they arrived. All good fun.$$Bromo,I love you....
Wait me for going there again.... :-*$$I have been there and really beautiful views ..I love Bromo$$Long time ago i was there

The beach located in the Banyuwangi Regency in Indonesia is a paradise for surfers that offer some of the most challenging waves in the world. #WonderfulIndonesia

Photo by Willy SouwIndonesia is most proud of the Plengkung Beach at the eastern tip of Java Island. Aside from its enchanting natural beauty, the long curving coast line here is recognized as one of the best surfing sites on the face of the earth. message+desc:
The vast expanse of Tinuy-An Falls literally made my jaw drop. Kawasan in Cebu, Hulugan in Laguna, or the towering Ganano Falls in Quirino are beautiful but Tinuy-An is something different altogether because of its expanse and landscape. During the day the sunlight hits the mists it creates and a small rainbow appears at the end of it. Definitely the crown jewel of Surigao del Sur.

Words and Photo by @carloenriquez21
#itsmorefuninthephilippines

Beautiful!$$It's a beautiful place..I was there last year 2014.$$I was there last August with my family love the place$$We've been there! Amazing place. Love to see again.$$explore north and visit this untouched paradise.

message+desc:
Dalhousie
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Located at an altitude of 1854.mts in the Chamba district of Himachal Pradesh, Dalhousie is one of India‚Äôs most well known holiday destinations. Named after Lord Dalhousie the British viceroy in India, this picturesque hill station, built around five hills, nestles in the outer slopes of the Dhauladhar range and attracts visitors who will be startled by its relaxed atmosphere, invigorating air, warm sunshine and quiet surroundings.
Here you will find some fine specimens of British colonial architecture. The unofficial honeymoon Mecca of India, Dalhousie is the reminiscent of an English town, with faded, elegant buildings evocative of another era. It is also becoming a haven for outdoor adventure activities, including trekking, cycling and rock climbing. 
- See more at: http://incredibleindia.org/index.php/travel/destination/dalhousie

Have you heard the name of the small island called Enoshima?
Enoshima is easy access from Tokyo, takes only one hour by train and also near Kamakura.

There is the Enoshima SeaCandle building and from the observation tower, a beautiful Mt. Fuji can be seen on a fine day. 
Let‚Äôs visit attractive Enoshima island during your stay in Tokyo and enjoy local food as well.
Related information:
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/kanagawa/enosima.html

Be there$$I was there 15 years ago..$$I was there last month, its a beautiful placeüåã$$Tsuritama!! message+desc:
1000th MEMBER CELEBRATION!!

Our 1000th member is Mr. Danny Tip!  Congratulations Danny, you are now the owner of this award winning Korean cookbook.  Please be sure to post photos of your creations for us later! 

MORE CHANCES TO WIN!

For the next 24 hours, we invite our fans to post here on our wall.  We want to know what place you most want to go to in Korea and your reason.  Or, if you have already been here, what was your favorite place and why?  

We will choose 4 of the best entries and send a copy of the cookbook to the winners as well!

We will take care of shipping.  

So are you ready?  You have 24 hours starting NOW!!!
comments:
My favorite place in Korea has to be Seoul. The real story of Seoul is not hidden in the tall skyscrapers or the ancient temples that encircle the urban center, but in a few important landmarks that are both historically significant and symbolic at the same time. Take Jongno street for instance. Better known as the "Bell Street," Jogno is famous for Bosingak, which is a marquee with a large bell. It is said the bell signals different times of a day and controls the four main gates to the city. The bell is usually rung thirty-three times at the midnight on New Year's Eve. However, when former president Kim Dae-jung took office in 1998, the bell was rung in the midst of an intense economic crisis that had hit the country. Every Korean worth his salt knows that Kim opened a new chapter of economic transparency and played an even greater role of steering the country on the world map by hosting international events such as the 2002 FIFA World Cup. The melancholic yet inspiring sound of the bell has definitely struck a chord with millions of locals and expats living in or across Seoul, just like me :)$$My favourite place is Incheon Airport.  It's a bitter-sweet feeling for me everytime I was there, the excitement when arriving and the sad feeling when departing...all beyond words.  The airport is always sparkling clean and alive, always welcoming to visitors and have good food and shopping to spend time before heading to the gate.  Best place to catch sun sets and to spot Rain. : )$$My favourite place in Korea is in Seoraksan National Park. At the peak of Daechongbong you can escape the hustle bustle of the city and get the ultimate view of the true beauty Korea has to offer. It‚Äôs a grueling climb to the top, but once there the scenery is breathtaking. You can see for miles on a clear day and bask in the peace at the top of the mountain. For me, Korea is largely about the mountains, and there is no better place to experience this.$$While we're on a food theme, it has to be Jeollado.  While I'd heard the food was going to be good (and it was), I'd also been led to expect the people to be a bit cold or tough.  Instead, I had some of my most memorable experiences on the road as people shared parts of their lives with me that I never expected.  In between that, I travelled deserted beaches on the south coast, walked through tea fields, dozed on a pagoda with a praying mantis in perhaps the prettiest temple I'd seen and cruised around glass-like seas.  And, of course, I ate.  A lot, well, and unusually, all prepared to an amazingly high standard (in a country that already had impressed me with the quality and care in its food).

Oh, and I highly recommend the goat.$$Call me a sentimental old fool, but it will have to be the old world charm of Andong for me. Even Queen Elizabeth II spent her birthday in Andong with a little celebration at the Soju Museum. Andong is the center of culture and folk traditions, noted for its serene beauty. I love history and Andong is steeped in it, right from the Three Kingdoms Period of Silla, Goguryeo and Baekje right up to the Joseon Dynasty. At the core of Andong‚Äôs long and illustrious past were numerous distinguished scholars, aristocrats and noblemen. It has the reputation of being the best preserved ancient metropolitan city. You can still find many of the homes of the noble class in Andong today. It used to be the centre for Confucianism at one point in Korean history. I may not be a follower of Confucianism but I respect some of their beliefs like justice and good manners are the key factors in life and I also admire their filial piety towards their elders.
Though the die-hard Confucians are not around anymore, Andong is one of the few places in the world where Confucian practices are still directly being passed down to its descendants to this day, as well as being a centre of education. Its current inhabitants are the direct descendants of those who actually occupied the houses in the Joseon Dynasty era. Because of its highly historical value, the village itself is often being referred to as a ‚Äòroofless museum‚Äô.
I would like to go to Andong to enjoy a stay in the traditional hanok guest houses available throughout the area. The Hahoe Village, Jirye Art Village, Jeonju Ryussi-musiljongtaek (Ryu noble family‚Äôs estate), I understand, are great places to experience a unique lodging experience and to sample the true essence of Korea‚Äôs traditional lifestyles. I just love traditional old houses and seowons and Andong is a treasure trove filled with them. The Andong Hahoe Folk Village which was designated Important Folk Material #122 is now up for nomination to become a World Heritage Site in 2010. Hahoe is especially known for its mask dances. The Dosan Confucian Academy, the Byeongsan Seowon Academy, 
Jirye Art Village, Andong Folk Museum, Goseong Lee head family Estate, Imcheonggak Pavillion, Ocheon Relics Site(village), the Hahoe Mask Museum and a 600-year-old zelkova tree in the Samshin-dang area are what I want to see in Andong. 

Perhaps my exposure to Korean movies/dramas set in the Joseon era, like Untold Scandal, Daejanggeum, Hwang Jini, Damo and Painter of the Wind have  contributed to my obsession of Andong.

I must not forget to mention the authentic Andong food that I want to try like heotjesatbap (this dish originates from the custom of using vegetables, meat, and seafood dishes left from memorial services) that includes Andong-style bibimbap.
Andong specialty that is sometimes included in the heot jesa bap is gan godeung-eo, or super, super salty mackerel. Some other Andong dishes include Andong Jjimdak, Andong Sikhye and Geonjin Guksu.
$$I have 3 favorite places in Korea: the Gyeongbokgung Palace, including Changdeokgung Palace (Rear Garden included), Changgyeonggung Palace, Deoksucgung Palace, and Joncgmyo Shrine. I'd like to stay at the "Secret Garden" that was intended for the King. I find peace and serenity while walking inside the palace grounds. The other place is the Korean Village. I want to live in the traditional 'Hanok" house and experience korean living. Lastly, Myeongdong, particularly, the Myeongdong Cathedral (Catholic Church).  Solemnity and solace in this place, is a sanctuary for me.$$@George Romeiser Hogan: thank you for those beautiful words as you describe Korea in your heart. You are right in every detail. You are both lucky to find each other in such a wonderful place like Korea. Perhaps, the one place I will always remember is that small korean restaurant (adjacent to Siloam Hospital) where I ate chajangmyeon with someone I was beginning to "like"... but who left me in the end... I miss korea so much, everything about it, and i'd like to go back someday...  and hopefully, live there one day.

message+desc: Several places in #Seoul offers many streets and paths to explore, including unique alleys and even an old railroad line that is transformed into a park! Tag your friends whom you'd wish to go to these places with on your next #VisitKorea trip! :)The perfect season to go on a walk is here ‚Äì fall! Don't get scammed!It's scary - genuine-looking fake websites of government agencies like the ICA and MOM have repeatedly surfaced.

Protect yourself with just a few simple steps to ensure the site you're on is legit.

https://mustsharenews.com/fake-government-websites/

Even WSJ, NYT and Economist have their websites laden with Outbrain ads - not to say CNA and Straits Times. Newspapers need to know how they are tarnishing their reputation by having such ad companies post on their websites, without clear demarkation that those are of non-journalistic content.

message+desc:
Check our latest webmagazine "Experience eco-tourism in Okinawa!"
In Okinawan dialect, "Yanbaru" refers to "a region full of mountains and forests". Okinawa has a strong image as a sea resort, but in fact its mountains and forests are also incredible. Have you experienced Okinawa's mountains and forests? Please tell us about your experiences of Okinawan nature!

http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/indepth/exotic/JapanesQue/special/okinawa003.htmlHome > Japan In-depth > JAPAN Monthly Web Magazine > Visit "Yanbaru" - a great natural environment exclusive to Okinawa
comments:
To whom it may concern,

First of all, I would like to send my warm greetings to you and your team. I am a Vietnamese undergraduate student in Hallym University, South Korea, and my major is Advertising and Public Relations. I am taking the course "Special topics in Public relations" which requires self-studying and research in a topic of choice. My topic is "The use of Social Media in Nation Branding", and I was wondering if you could provide me some information regarding your activities. For example, how you find this page (or other SNS) effective in terms of promoting your country, what kind of information you post and the interactions with fans/users, the number of fans you have and how it increased in time. If you could provide me some statistics of the page, that would be really wonderful! I also wish to know that in your perspective, how different the social media and traditional media are, in terms of use and effectiveness for Nation Branding purpose. Any information that you give will be used for class assignment only. I highly appreciate your help and I am sorry if this bothers you. I also want to say that I think you and your team are doing a great job with the page. I really want to visit your country in the future. 

Thank you very much. 

Best regards,
Jang Pham

message+desc:
Where is it?
Olango Islands, Cebu

How to Get There:
Olango Islands, Cebu

What is it?
This island group is composed of the main Olango Island and its six satellite islets. The site is a wildlife sanctuary that serves as a pit stop for migratory birds that come from as far as China, Japan and Siberia. 

Fun Fact:
The seven islands of the Olango group are joined together by a continuous reef. This makes the site a nice diving spot as well.

Photo by / Headline by:
Tourism Department Philippines / Jap Bautista

From airport, ride Punta Enga√±o multicab and disembark at Movenpick Hotel (for Hilton Port).
For Agsangil Wharf, ride Maribago-Soong multicab then disembark near Mactan Newtown. Take tricycle or habal habal to Agsangil Wharf.

Banca ride is 15 minutes, depending on weather conditions. You'll disembark at Santa Rosa Wharf at Olango island.

Hope this helps.

message+desc:
Sometimes, we are so blinded focusing on the negatives that we forget the things we do have. And when we travel the world, that's when it hits us.

I hated SMRT breakdowns till I went to Australia and had to wait 1 hour for my bus because that's how often they came. When I was stuck in a jam in Bangkok for an hour, I decided getting off and walking would be faster.

Sure, it's very easy to complain about everything, but let's not be that angry Singaporean. Here are 8 facts that'll make you proud to call Singapore home.

http://thesmartlocal.com/read/happy-facts-sgWe Singaporeans love complaining, but there are so many blessings we constantly take for granted. Here are 8 things all Singaporeans should be thankful for!
comments:
There's also the efficiency issue. My friend had to wait almost two weeks before his Internet got set up when he moved to Manchester. That sort of nonsense is unheard of here.$$should let S'porean feel to have no electricity for 2 consecutive days and water$$Some Singaporeans are just not thinking realistically, expecting everything in Sg to be perfect...including our standard of governance.  Would we be here talking about these things if they are so lousy?. They may not be perfect but to be fair, aren't that bad. Might I ask who else can do it better than them presently?
Many have travel and seen the world yet can't do a real comparison between us and other countries ....sad!$$Yes!
I told my mom when trapped inside mrt train last year... she thought i must be angry but i just told her better than when i was in Bangkok anyway, it was like hell over there. 3hrs trapped in mrt is better than living in terrible Bangkok!$$Probably im the only Singaporean that doesnt complain. Been to Malaysia and Indonesia, thank God im lucky to be born In Singapore ‚ù§$$44 deg heat with no air con in an old car in australia...Singaporean need to experience this once in their lifetime and they'll never complain about traffic again! Lol$$All is so true Singapore is just spot on$$Try driving in Jakarta's rush hour :)$$Why compare with Bangkok when you can compare with Japan ? If you want to compare with bkk, why not other things like affordable housing, cars, pace and cost of living ? If you want to feel good about yourself why stop at bkk? Compare your life with Palestinian ones la!$$True, but if you want to compare the areas which other countries are worse off than Singapore, you also need to compare all the areas which other countries are better off than Singapore. It works both ways.$$30 minutes traffic is not bad. I love the public transportation in Singapore. Nothing compared here in Manila. Imagine going to work on Monday morning and going back home on tuesday early morning due to traffic and flood.$$Singapore's geographic area is also 1/10 of these places. Why not more specific comparisons to cities of similar size and GDP? Maybe Hongkong or Seoul? Albeit our transportation remains the top of the curve in comparison to most major cities in the world, it doesn't make a fair comparison simply in terms of land mass.$$We are still using ADSL mind you....one big difference between Sg and oz was the "speed" of the internet here. I reckon my grandpa could ran quicker than loading a page in Oz! Lolll$$Well, the next time a Singaporean minister embarrasses the nation by comparing other countries unfavourably to us, let's not jump on him or her then yeah?$$Sawadee Jao. We welcome you to come to Bangkok to see our jam. Singaporean very lucky. Jam in aircon bus, even must stand is still comfort. In Bangkok, jam in bus no aircon, and no place for sit, and bus start-stop-start-stop and very hot chiphai. 
Singapore also have very good data network when jam have Line for chat with friend. Bangkok data not fast same Singapore.

Why Singaporean complain I don't know. Why Singapore make so many road toll for make driver pay, so no jam, I also don't know. 

I think Singaporean all must come Bangkok visit see jam and experience.

Come, visit Bangkok. Spend your money in our Chatuchak so Thai economy can be boost same Singapore always every year improve. 
Come support our industry in the day time and the night time for Thailand take care you from when you wake up to when you sleeping and even when you sleeping we have way to take care you.$$Their cars are cheaper. Ours are world's most expensive. We hv paid for having less traffic jam. Grateful ?$$Damaris Skillecorn this came up
on my FB feed. Hope you are not yet at the stage where you need positive singapore facts! x$$Opportunity cost is higher in sg with such hectic lifestyle that we live in.$$The geographical , demographic and econmoics are ways too different to make comparison.$$We must learn to step out of our hermit shell and start to appreciate the things around us.$$Please tell 30% nuts in Singapore üá∏üá¨! They still dreaming & complained everyday!$$As long as we keep our population under 5M then we shouldn't see such issues.$$Just go to Jakarta and feel the sensation ! üòÑ

message+desc:
Ukai, cormorant fishing season will be coming soon at Nagaragawa River, Gifu Pref!
Ukai is a traditional method of catching small Japanese trout by manipulating seabirds called u (cormorants) in the Nagaragawa River, famous for its limpid stream, in Gifu Prefecture. Master trainers of cormorants dressed in ancient costume freely manipulate 10-12 wild sea cormorants to skillfully catch small trout. This fishing is performed every night between May 11th and October 15th except during a full moon or in heavy rain. You can watch the entire spectacle aboard a small wooden boat while dining and drinking sake!
More detail: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/festival/ukai.html
Area video: http://www.visitjapan.jp/en/video/?id=107
Check out other events in May:
 http://www.jnto.go.jp/special_events/eng/index.php?month=5
Photo courtesy: Gifu City
comments: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KKfKMSNsdFM$$Hi, I'm from NW Ohio, on my first trip to Japan, In 1999, I was a month long chaperone, my host family took me here.$$I may need to try this I can't catch a fish any other way lol$$I want to try this if I can make it to Kyoto in July. As long as I can sit and drink sake.$$Masashi Kotake - is this close to you?$$How do they took the fish from the bird??$$http://youtu.be/QVLV8ihCQKI

message+desc:
So exciting!
Hakata Gion Yamakasa Festival of Kushida Shrine, takes place at Fukuoka City in Kyushu from July 1st to 15th. 
The highlight of this festival comes on July 15th, when Yamakasa, gorgeously decorated floats topped with elaborate decorations including miniature castles, flowers and historical heros' dolls are drawn one after another by young men starting from the Shrine every 5 min. from 4:59 am to around 5:30 am through the crowds of spectators. The floats are on display at 14 different places in the city during the festival period. Many more events are scheduled during the period. Enjoy!

Related Information;
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/festival/hakatagionyamakasa.html
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/fukuoka/hakata.html

No more paying $20 for raindrop cakes. You can now make it at home!With only 4 ingredients needed, a raindrop cake is way easier to make than you think!

Raindrop cakes, or Mizu Shingen Mochi, are traditionally made with water and agar-agar, and served with roasted soybean flour and dark brown sugar syrup for added flavour. But to make things more interesting, we added a coconut spin, and made it with kitchen equipment you already have as well as ingredients you can buy from any supermarket. 

Get the full recipe at Eatbook.sg:
eatbook.sg/raindrop-cake-recipe

message+desc:
The Merlion Tower is one place Singaporeans know to avoid. (Poor tourists!) Check out these hilarious reviews by our members!

Steadyhands: "I just couldn't give this place a zero rating. So, it's a 0.5 in lieu of a zero. Sentosa should either open up the Merlion as an observation tower for free or tear it down. And stop charging entry fees! "

Lansell Taudevin: "I love Sentosa. I am aware that the Merlion is a significant icon in Singapore. But the Merlion Tower is at the bottom of the pile of interesting things to do.

What do you do? You pay your money. You watch an introductory video n the mythological origins of the Merlion. (Try and stay awake) You travel to the top. You walk out. You walk around. You look. You go back down. You pass through yet another souvenir shop. You pause. You star back to the top, where you were a few moments ago, and you ask yourself: "What the???"

Sorry, Merle, there are so many more fascinating things to do on Sentosa, and for the $8 admission fee I can buy one and a half ice creams."

http://www.thesmartlocal.com/sg/attractions/5579-the-merlion-tower-sentosaPhotos, Directions & Insider Reviews by Locals - The Merlion Tower and Merlion Walk is an attraction in Sentosa that explores the origins of Singapore's most famous mythological icon.
comments: It's absolutely tragic!

message+desc:
Himeji castle, one of UNESCO world heritage site, is now under reconstruction until 2015. During the period, there are special facilities for the restoration, provide visitors with the opportunity to have a close look at the exterior of the highest level (fifth floor) and large roof of the main keep while it is being restored. If you are lucky, you may witness the skilled craftsmen repairing plaster walls and replacing roofing tiles!
Location information: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/hyogo/himejijo.html
Photo courtesy: Daisuke Yatsui

HIMEJI CASTLE RE-OPENING IN MARCH 27, 2015
Himeji Castle, a designated World Heritage Site, brought back to life in its original shape of 400 years ago. Himeji Castle, a famous castle also called "Hakurojo" or White Heron Castle, is one of the 4 castles that have their main keeps intact as it was when constructed. 3 Himeji residents fully enjoyed the experience at Himeji Castle and Japanese culture before its full opening.

message+desc:
Our national language, Filipino, isn't that hard to learn.  That's why some foreigners have managed to speak it quite fluently. Check out eight of these foreigners who know how to speak Filipino so well, they're almost Pinoy! 

http://8list.ph/foreigners-who-speak-tagalog/Who said only Pinoys can celebrate Buwan ng Wika?
comments:
Philippine languages are mixture of  spanish & american english like wen you count uno,dos tres,..... its in spanish but commonly Philippine use it.$$Alex Compton should be on this list.$$I want to learn soon :)$$I want to learn also :-)$$I surely agree with some of the comments here that the philippine language is tagalog...and now it's officialy been revised and as for me, i am not awareüòî$$Hi guys! Great that you wanna learn more about our language, which is officially Filipino. Kindly see the link. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Filipino_language$$I want to learn too but no german-tagalog books there. :-($$I beg to disagree to Ms. Gretchen Filart Dublin. You are right, our nationality is Filipino but our language is also called Filipino and NOT Tagalog. Because there are lots of dialects existing in our country.$$Tagalog is just one of the dialects we have. we actually.do not have a national language...atleast the last time I was there..$$Pilipino is the national languages  of tagalogs, but not to the cebuanos....$$That is amazing.  Im Filipino and I cant speak the language anymore.$$@theresa berano goldenberg remember @ work I always talk to u in tagalog kasi I want u to learn
But I know u like filipino food$$There's always this feeling of 'pride' when I hear foreigners speaking in Tagalog language.$$thou must not forget this guy:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W60YBUPSNko$$moreover, Tagalog IS the national language.
Filipino is the term used in identifying the Tagalog dialect of Metro Manila.$$Being a filipina who used to live in our beautiful country that is Philippines,,im proud to say that many foreign people love to know & want to speak our national language,called Tagalog.
Mabuhay tayo

message+desc:
Bonsai ‚Äì natural beauty in sophisticated form Saitama Bonsai city
 
The Omiya Bonsai Village (Saitama Pref.) is known as one of the most outstanding bonsai cultivating areas in Japan. Bonsai is a Japanese art form using miniature trees grown in containers. Artists use sophisticated techniques to grow small trees beautiful. Let‚Äôs feel the Japanese traditional art of bonsai that has been handed down over hundreds of years.
 
Saitama Area
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/saitama/index.html

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Boracay, Aklan

What is it like? 
While Filipinos typically celebrate Christmas at home, some get away from the maddening rush and escape to nearby beaches like Boracay. Resorts and hotels prepare Christmas buffets for guests on Christmas eve and Christmas day, so they won't miss the traditional Noche Buena (Christmas feast). This is why December is considered by resorts and airlines as peak season, and you have to book your tickets and room way in advance.

Fun Fact: 
Children from Boracay are expert sand-castle makers, and for a small token you can ask them to sculpt one in the shape of your name or your sweetheart's!

Photo by/Author: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Tin Sanchez
comments: That's what you call " white as snow ", only in Boracay, Philippines. :)$$Was in the Philippines in the 60s$$Over night on way to nam$$Philippines are so beautiful$$Best beach in the World üòÑ!!!!$$its not a snowman but it SANDMAN hahaha$$Forgot the #airportproblem...#itsmorefuninthephilippines$$Wow of the philippines....$$its more fun in the philippines!$$Merry Christmas to you & your family.God Bless$$That's were we are right now :) Jose Luis Retamal$$https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_RtSu3woTKM$$That's an idea, a sand snowman$$Its truly more fun in the philippines

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Rizal Park, Manila

What is it? 
At the heart of Manila you‚Äôll find Rizal Park, which commemorates the national hero of the Philippines. This is the spot where Jose Rizal was executed by firing squad, igniting the Filipino revolution.

How to get there: 
Fly into Manila through one of more than 30 international airlines. You can also fly in from any major Philippine city.

Or take a bus from any major city in Luzon.

Or take a boat from any major Philippine port.

Fun Fact: 
There are a lot of Filipino Martial Arts groups that use the park as their training area. Come during Sunday mornings and you might chance upon a stickfighting duel!

Photo by/Headline by: 
George Tapan/Brandon Dollente
comments: Notice no DMCI Torre de Manila Building at the back...

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Sunken Cemetery, Camiguin

What is it like? 
Diving in Camiguin is sure to be interesting if you visit sites such as the sunken cemetery. Once above ground, this WWII burial ground now sits underwater and is a popular tourist attraction.

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila to Cagayan de Oro.

Or take a boat from Manila, Iloilo, or Cebu to Cagayan de Oro.

Then take a bus to Balingoan, and then a boat to Camiguin Island.

Fun Fact: 
The cemetery, along with parts of the town of Bonbon, sunk because of an earthquake that created Mt. Vulcan.

Photo by/Headline by: 
Joey Rico/Meggy De Guzman
comments: Hi Rosselle. This is in Camiguin.$$Wehey! bayan ng aking ama yan.. come & enjoy the small town in camiguin.. 8s more fun in camiguin island of the phil. Byahe na at enjoy the town of camiguin 8s more touristspots dscovering..

message+desc: The Philippines is indeed the "Pearl of the Orient" #itsmorefuninthePhilippinesPhilippine officials believe they may have recovered the biggest natural giant clam pearl in the world - weighing a whopping 34kg (5.2 stone).
comments:
Wow!! Must have taken several centuries to naturally form this rare pearl., bred in the richest marine ecosystem that Palawan is ! üëèüèºüëèüèºüëèüèºüëèüèºüáµüá≠$$It took more than five weeks to locate the secretive dog slaughterhouse. Raiding it almost cost a Network for Animals activist his life.
We located the building in the south of the Philippine mainland. An innocuous house at the end of a dirt road, hiding a grim secret: an illegal dog slaughtering operation, protected by well-paid security guards, who swung into action every time the killing commenced.

Our team secretly monitored the building. The heat, humidity, mosquito and ant bites took their toll. But it was nothing compared to what the poor dogs would experience:
Forced into rusting metal cages, their sensitive noses would know the aging scent of canine blood on the air. They must know their time is short, because those cages are hell-on-earth. Excruciating temperatures, horrific humidity, and nowhere to rest but on-or-under the bodies of your cell mates. No water. No food. No hope.
The illegal slaughterhouse owner earns more than $11,000 each month and protects his business with a pistol and fierce temper. Our team leader Mel and his companion Perry knew this when they were discovered hiding in bushes on July 14th. Mel ran until he almost fainted, but Perry was not so fast, or so lucky: He was captured.

Mel quickly returned to the slaughterhouse with the only available policeman. When it became clear that Perry had been abducted, four more officers arrived. Achingly slowly, the terrifying situation was diffused. 36 dogs were seized, and eventually our teammate was returned safely from the hostage situation. It could have been so much worse.$$WE LOVE AND PROTECT THE NATURE IN THE PHILIPPINES! GOD BLESS US...$$I feel sorry for the clam who had to endure the pain of making that thing for god knows how long$$Pearl of the orient indeed Philippines$$agree, Phils is the '' Pearl of the Orient ''$$Philippines is one of the wealthiest nation on earth.$$Germaiine Ng that's the real pearl if the orient...$$How about the fisherman? I hope he was paid well...$$Pearl of the Orient my country.$$Please appeal to the Puerto Princesa City government and tourism office to richly compensate the fisherman who found it.$$WE HAVE IT ALSO THE GIANT CLAMS IN OUR MARINE PROTECTED AREA IN SAN JUAN, BATANGAS. HOPEFULLY WE WILL BE HAVE IT THE SAME NATURAL GIANT CLAM PEARL SOMEDAY... VERY INSPIRING... WE PRAY..$$Imagine he was living with this treasure for a decade!!?? Just wow.$$George Hatfield show mum this article and tell her it's like the Steinbeck book

message+desc:
Khajuraho - Eternal Expressions of Love

The temples of Khajuraho are India's unique gift to the world, representing, as they do, a paean to life, to love, to joy, perfect in execution and sublime in expression. Life, in every form and mood, has been captured in stone, testifying not only to the craftsman's artistry but also to the extraordinary breadth of vision of the Chandela Rajputs under whose rule the temples were conceived and constructed. 
The Khajuraho temples were built in the short span of a hundred years, from 950-1050 AD in truly inspired burst of creativity. Of the 85 original temples, 22 have survived till today to constitute one of the world's great artistic wonders. 

- See more at: http://www.incredibleindia.org/travel/destination/khajuraho
comments: in the world great artistiques temples castle monuments are the history!yes is wonderful

Where Is It?
Anilao, Batangas

How to Get There: 
Take a bus to Batangas from Cubao or Pasay.

What Is it?
Anilao is just a two-hour road trip from Manila, and has excellent waters for snorkeling and diving. It‚Äôs famous for its biologically diverse waters, and of course, its warm temperate waters that lets you dive in shorties.

Fun Fact: 
This place is also popular for underwater macro photography.

Photo by / Headline by: 
Tourism Department Philippines / Meggy de Guzman

message+desc: Haerang Luxury Railroad Cruise
comments:
wow thats expensive for a 2 night 3 day trip$$Korea is very economical for people travelling on a budget. Not everyone is however, and some people (especially retired folks) want to pay for all the comforts.  To cater to these people, the Korean travel industry has begun to put together some special tours. This is one of them.

If you are a backpacker and want to do your own tour of Korea by train, you can easily get around at an affordable price. Please feel free to ask us questions and we can help plan :).

I think most of our KTO fanpage members are in younger age demographics, so perhaps I shouldn't have posted this here... sorry guys :)$$Here is one option for an economical train adventure:
http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_1_1_1.jsp?cid=1064143

This train travels along the ocean, and the seats are all facing toward the window so its easy to take in the view!$$Coming this winter you can also take the High 1 train snowboarding :)
http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_6.jsp?cid=262770$$I want to take the sea train!$$The Aura Tour sounds terrific!$$I would like to ask for the adventure train is it include in the korail pass?
$$@Jennifer- do you mean the sea train? $$Thanks very much, we love train travel. We would love to do the Haerang trip but it is a lot, would be one for a future trip.  For our visit soon we want to go to the Sea Train and I have spent the last hour looking into the High1 area link you put.  We will be there in Autumn and have been thinking about Seoraksan but this looks like it would be good in Autumn too.$$The Sea Train would have to be purchased separately from the Korail pass. The reservation page is all in Korean, but they say that if you call them they will make a reservation for you over the phone in English.  033-573-5473 $$@Lea thanks for the feedback :)  I love travelling by train, I think it is a great way to see the country.  Oh you might like the Wine Train too!

http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/SI/SI_EN_3_1_1_1.jsp?cid=1065096

message+desc:
Why don‚Äôt you visit HOZUKI ICHI in Tokyo!
This fair is usually held in June and July at some temples or shrines, such as Atago Shrine on June 23 & 24 and most famous one at Sensoji Temple in Asakusa on July 9 & 10. It is told that people visiting this temple on this day can be counted as visiting the temple for a whole life.
‚ÄúHozuki‚Äù which can be called ‚ÄúWinter Cherry‚Äù was known as a medical herb and people used to buy this while visiting the temple. There are almost 450 vendors in the precincts of Sensoji Temple.
In this season, during your stay in Japan, you may find the beautiful red ‚ÄúHozuki‚Äù at the Market!
 http://www.gotokyo.org/en/kanko/taito/event/hozmaturi.html

Calendar Events June 2014>
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/pdf/event/calendar_events_201406.pdf

message+desc:
Where is it?
Mt. Malasimbo, Puerto Galera, Oriental Mindoro

How to Get There:
Puerto Galera is a 1.5 hour bus or car trip from Manila to Batangas and a 1 to 2 hour ferry boat ride to reach Puerto Galera. Public and Private Ferries are available, or you may also bring your car via the RORO.

What is it?
The Malasimbo Lights and Dance Festival is an international music festival focused on hip hop, house and electronic music. Set at the foothills of Mt. Malasimbo where the grass-terraced amphitheater overlooks the sparkling blue bay. International acts perform on stage as accompanied by state of the art light shows. The festival continues to grow with more than 5,000 people from over 30 countries in attendance.

Fun Fact:
Apart from the festivals, Malasimbo is also known for it's eco-cultural activities. The d'Aboville Foundation, along with the festival helps promote mangrove planting, the use of solar energy, the protection of the endangered tamaraw and coastal cleanups.
comments: I suggest you bring your own food and drinks in this event. Too expensive! Hahaha the location itself is superb though. :)$$When is the festival ?$$were been there already!$$it happens in 2 weekends so that's last weekend & there's another one this weekend :)$$Can we visit this place anytime? What about hotels?

message+desc:
Nagasari merupakan kue yang terbuat dari tepung beras, tepung sagu, santan, dan gula serta diisi dengan pisang. Kue ini biasanya dikemas dalam gulungan daun pisang sebelum akhirnya dikukus. Selain daun pisang, daun pandan juga sering dijadikan alternatif untuk membungkus nagasari. Hasilnya, aroma yang dihasilkan kue ini begitu khas. Meski berasal dari Jogjakarta, namun kue yang satu ini bisa dengan mudah ditemukan di seluruh Nusantara. 
#PesonaIndonesia #KulinerIndonesia
comments: Dedi Junaedi I've tried it before, yummy! :)

message+desc:
Where is it?
University of Santo Tomas, Manila 

What is it?
The  University of Santo Tomas (UST) is the oldest university in Asia. It was founded in 1611 by the Archbishop of Manila. The university has been declared a National Historical Landmark by the National Historical Commission of the Philippines.

Fun Fact:
UST is one of the world's largest Catholic universities.

Photo by Isai Martinez

message+desc:
Where is it?
Boracay, Aklan

How to Get There:
"Fly from Manila to Caticlan.

Or fly from Manila to Kalibo, then take a bus to Caticlan.

Or take a boat from Manila to Caticlan."

What is it?
While Filipinos typically celebrate Christmas at home, some get away from the maddening rush and escape to nearby beaches like Boracay. Resorts and hotels prepare Christmas buffets for guests on Christmas eve and Christmas day, so they won't miss the traditional Noche Buena (Christmas feast). This is why December is considered by resorts and airlines as peak season, and you have to book your tickets and room way in advance.

Fun Fact:
Children from Boracay are expert sand-castle makers, and for a small token you can ask them to sculpt one in the shape of your name or your sweetheart's!

Photo by / Headline by:
Tourism Department Philippines / Tin Sanchez
comments:
This picture shows ingenuity of this great culture. Philippines' best resource is the people!$$who say's we can't have a White Christmas in the Philippines? i love it!$$well... that's a good way to spend your christmas ^^$$Likit, build a sandman.$$This is the kind of Christmas I definitely want to have! ;)$$Merry Christmas, everyone! Greet the world with the hashtag #longestchristmasphilippines!$$Subic Ay! Supports and Promotes Philippine Tourism!

We support this Page!

Like Our Page too...

https://www.facebook.com/subicay?ref=hl

message+desc:
[New Guide] 12 Words Singaporeans have been mispronouncing their whole lives.

Is flour pronounced "FLAR" OR "FLOWER?"

Here are 12 words Singaporeans have been mispronouncing all their lives. 

Yes, we are all guilty!!!!! 99.9% of Singaporeans mispronounce #9!

http://www.thesmartlocal.com/read/words-singaporeans-mispronounce99.9% of Singaporeans mispronounce #9. Here are 12 words Singaporeans have been mispronouncing all their lives.
comments:
We are not native English speakers... so I don't really care... I hv Scottish friends who pronounce Monday as mourn day. We are still good in our English compared to many countries ....included our written standards to some white countries...The article is a good eye opener... room for improvements$$But in general, I hope that we would one day be able to tell others that WE ARE NOT WRONG. just like there is UK and AMERICAN pronunciation, we have our local version of pronunciation. As long as the whole country pronounce the same way. So please tell me how to pronounce LETTUCE.$$It's not the pronunciation;as someone above said; all languages affect the way people pronounce English. It's the whole acceptance of singlish  that I find disturbing!$$Imagine I ask for flar at the florist.... the aunty will say " siao cha boa....no no no... ntuc see... go ntuc ah ok gal" when in rome live like the romans$$Lol good summary! Almost every word sounds weird from the local pronunciation..$$flour & flower have the same pronounciation, which u can find in dictionary. if u argue of having different dialect or way of pronounciation in different country, its not entirely wrong.$$http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_tlsQrgBdDM$$1) Opinion seems to be divided on the pronunciation of ‚Äúflour‚Äù in the British dictionaries I consulted. The Oxford Concise Dictionary (1995) and the Oxford Advanced Learner‚Äôs Dictionary (2005) indicate that ‚Äúflour‚Äù has the same pronunciation as ‚Äúflower‚Äù, i.e.: 

 /‚Äôflau-e(r)/ ‚Äì a two-syllabled word with the stress on the first syllable ‚Äì the ‚Äúe‚Äù is a schwa, like the ‚Äòe‚Äô sound in ‚Äúmoment‚Äù).  

However, the 20-volume Oxford English Dictionary (1989) and the online Cambridge Advanced Learner‚Äôs Dictionary show ‚Äúflour‚Äù being pronounced as:  

 /flaue(r)/ ‚Äì a one-syllabled word with three vowels together (a triphthong), the ‚Äòe‚Äô in it being also a schwa. Because of the combination of the three vowels in a syllable, we tend to glide over them, resulting in a sound resembling /fla(r)/.   

 I consider both pronunciations to be correct alternative pronunciations. In fact, there is also an alternative pronunciation of ‚Äúflower‚Äù, indicated by the 20-volume OED, which is exactly like the second pronunciation of ‚Äúflour‚Äù!$$Can blame Bon Jovi for mispronouncing "prayer".

Americans apparently pronounce "algae" as al-jai
Dictionary.Cambridge.org/dictionary/british/algae?q=algae#$$Missed out my fav gahment instead of government ;(

message+desc:
Hakone Hydrangea Train <June-July>
The hydrangeas along the Hakone Tozan Railway tracks are in full bloom every year in mid June. The hydrangeas bloom from the lower part of the mountain due to the different temperatures according to the altitude, with the final blossoms at the top at the end of July. The hydrangeas grow very close to the train and you can almost touch them from the window!
National Park Hakone (Kanagawa) http://www.hakone.or.jp/english/index.html
Hakone Area http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/kanagawa/hakone.html

message+desc:
Varkala - Breathtaking destination not to be missed
------------------------------------------------------------------------

A famous beach destination in southern Kerala, Varkala comes lauded as a sacred pilgrimage center too. Like the white cliffs of Dover, the pink  cliffs at the Varkala Beach offer sensational view of the Arabian Sea. Mineral water springs originating from the cliff is believed to possess medicinal properties. 

A dip in the holy waters at the beach is believed to purge the body of impurities and the soul of all sins; hence the name 'Papanasam beach'. The place is home to 2000-year-old Vishnu Shrine of Janardhanaswamy. The Sivagiri Mutt established by the great social reformer, Sree Narayana Guru is another start attraction of the place. 

- See more at: http://incredibleindia.org/index.php/travel/destination/varkala

message+desc:
Where is it?
Sagada, Mountain Province

What is it?
It may be hidden, and the path to it may not be for the weak-hearted, but those who have visited Bomod-Ok Falls in Sagada will tell you that every aching muscle and groaning joint was worth the trip. After all, Sagada is known for its gorgeous natural scenery. 

Fun Fact: 
Have your swimsuit ready so you can reward yourself with a cool dip after all the hiking! A nearby picnic area makes it the ideal lunch spot for travelers as well!

Photo by Joey Rico

message+desc:
Enjoy the beautiful summer's visual phenomena of framing!
In traditional Japanese buildings such as temples, there are places where you can appreciate picture-perfect natural scenery through a window, making the scene look like a framed work of art. Every season, each scene brings us the different feeling.

Related Information;
http://japan-magazine.jnto.go.jp/en/1409_foliage.html
comments: It is part of the art of designing and building buildings and gardens (the better ones, at least), in China and Japan, that these kinds of views are deliberately designed, and not accidental or fortuitous. Ask those who designed & built the Chinese Gardens in Sydney (.au), for instance. It would be good if our Western architects considered these things too, considered the view from inside, considered what the users/residents see and feel, rather than just banks and banks of the same, the same old convenience-plants out the front and up the side. Rather than designing building that look like rubbish, crumpled cardboard box look in a 20-storey building and so forth.$$Kinda a random question but when these are shut, do they keep mosquitoes out?$$Hello i am Eng Stephen from United state of America i am looking for some workers in my house such as Nanny, Gardner, Cook and Driver Home Nurse,Private Teacher,Security, Waiter .. Kindly get back to me if you are interested in working in the US...You can contact me directly through my email or skype... eng.stephenlawrence@yahoo.com skype name stephen.lawrence183$$http://workonlineguide2.blogspot.com/2015/07/the-most-beautiful-horses.html

message+desc:
nanKTM Shuttle: Singapore To JB On An Old-School Train In 5 Mins

Skip causeway jams forever.

http://thesmartlocal.com/read/ktm-shuttle-guide
comments:
I've done this trip a number of times in both directions and this is hands down the most efficient and comfortable way to cross the causeway, just make sure to book your tickets in advance for peak times. You go through a separate customs so you don't get caught in the human jam and the train isn't subject to traffic jams, even during peak times on public holidays the whole process form JB Sentral to Woodlands CIQ or reverse takes about 20 minutes including immigration.

I've been stuck in 4 hour jams at immigration before and traffic jams so bad decided to ditch the bus and walk the causeway. The KTM train is the best option.

Here's the link to book online with KTMB

https://intranet.ktmb.com.my/e-ticket/login.aspx$$5 minutes is maximum allowed time, actual journey time is about 3 minutes.

message+desc:
Nagaland - Rich traditional and cultural heritage, amidst a diversity of nature

The state is bounded by Arunachal Pradesh and parts of Assam in the North, Manipur is the South, Myanmar on the East and Assam in the West. Nagaland is a vibrant hill state that offers an incomparably rich traditional and cultural heritage. Nagaland is inhabited by 16 major tribes along with sub-tribes. Each of the 16 tribes and sub-tribes hasits own languages, customs and traditions. Nagaland is largely a mountainous, rich in flora and fauna. Very little is known of Naga history before the Burmese invasion of 1816 and the area‚Äôs inclusion into East India Company‚Äôs dominion.

- See more at: http://www.incredibleindia.org/travel/destination/nagaland

message+desc:
Kyoto‚Äôs Kitchen ~Nishiki Market~
If you are looking for places where you can have local food in Kyoto, have you heard of Nishiki Market? It is said that the market began about 700 years ago and has been loved ever since by local people. You can grab something to eat while walking through the arcade too!

The photos on the right side are vegetable pickles, they go well with rice! Have you ever tried Japanese pickles?

Nishiki Market: http://www.kyoto-nishiki.or.jp/english/ 
One Day Trip Plan in Kyoto: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/routes/g_route/golden_osaka1.html
comments: Kim & Brian - You may want to check this out . . .$$Nishiki is a great place to have lunch - however, we recommend walking through the market first so you get an idea of the many options available and then only buy on your way back. There is so much to choose from. And Japanese pickles are delicious!

message+desc:
Ekspedisi kapsul waktu membawa sebanyak 3 kendaraan roda empat akan berkeliling menuju 34 provinsi seluruh Indonesia. Salah satu kendaraan membawa sebuah tabung berbentuk kapsul berukuran lebih kurang 50 sentimeter. Kapsul tersebut nantinya akan diisi surat-surat yang bertuliskan mimpi dan harapan anak-anak Indonesia yang ingin dicapai di masa depan. 

Kementerian Pariwisata mendukung kegiatan Ekspedisi Kapsul Waktu 2085, sebagai bagian Gerakan Nasional Ayo Kerja yang dicanangkan Presiden Jokowi. Masyarakat Belitung bersama Menteri Pariwisata Arief Yahya akan menyambut kehadiran Ekspedisi Kapsul Waktu di Bumi Laskar Pelangi Tanjung Tinggi, hari ini 13 Oktober 2015. #PesonaIndonesia

Fly Business Class! - Korea's Worth The Trip

Where is it?
Camiguin Island, Mindanao

How to Get There:
"Fly from Manila to Cagayan de Oro.

Or take a boat from Manila, Iloilo, or Cebu to Cagayan de Oro.

Then take a bus to Balingoan, and then a boat to Camiguin Island."

What is it?
Camiguin is known as "the island born of fire" because of its seven volcanoes. It‚Äôs a less touristy site, with most visitors coming to see White Island ‚Äì a sandbar with a view of Hibok-Hibok Volcano and Mt. Vulcan.

Fun Fact:
Camiguin is the second-smallest island-province in the Philippines.

Photo by / Headline by:
Joey Rico / Rachel Teotico

Tokyo's brand new landmark, Tokyo Sky Tree will open on May 22.
At 634m in height, it's the tallest free-standing tower in the world. Want to see the panoramic view from the observatory? We will feature spectacular view from the 450m high on our next web magazine!  Don't miss it!

Find out more about a day in Mr. Salleh's life here: http://thesmartlocal.com/read/last-postman

This is not sponsored content.

message+desc:
You might know Hokkaido for its magnificent nature and food, or perhaps snow.
But remember that industrial sites tour can also be enjoyed in Hokkaido.

‚ÄúShiroi Koibito (meaning White Lover in Japanese)‚Äù is a popular confection, produced by the leading confectionery company based in Hokkaido. At Shiroi Koibito Park, you can join factory tour, and participate in a workshop of baking one!
Some of you might also know beer called ‚ÄúSapporo.‚Äù There is Sapporo Beer Museum and the facility provides varied knowledge of beer history and equipment. Tasting Lounge provides you variety of beers. 
Also, at the Wine Castle, you will be fulfilled with one of the Hokkaido's original wines called Tokachi Wine.
If you have a chance to visit Hokkaido, add industrial sightseeing on your to-do list!

Related Information:

http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/spot/indutour/sapporobeer.html

message+desc:
You and your friend can lounge at this luxurious resort for 3 days when you win #TagTheFun photo contest!

Astoria Palawan is an eco-friendly resort found in the famous Puerto Princesa in Palawan. The establishment is situated on a five-hectare mango orchard with a retention pond that is used for recreation as a source of water. The materials adapted for the construction are green building materials. With its rustic and modern architecture, they aim to be loyal on having an environmental design to ensure travelers feel one with nature throughout their stay.

Astoria Palawan has 40 spacious and elegant rooms. The studio rooms are 38 sqm, the 1 bedroom suite is 56 sqm while the 2 bedroom site is 91 sqm. All accommodations have either a cozy king-size bed or two queen-size beds. The suites have a separate living and dining areas. Amenities also include TV with cable, kitchenette, air-conditioned rooms and complimentary coffee. Guests can enjoy the numerous facilities such as the swimming pool, dining areas, and avail of several tours such as exploring the Honda Bay Islands or the Puerto Princesa Subterranean River National Park.

www.agoda.com/morefunph
http://bit.ly/1KZRZiv
