message+desc:
Why Young Singaporeans Think Their Lives Suck

Our generation has it far better than any other but we struggle daily to find fulfillment and happiness. 

Our #firstworldproblems mentality means we get annoyed when we realise we have to pay to download some apps - but our parents problem was not even having toys to play with. They had to make their own out of cut out cardboard. Yet they were happier than us.

So why are so we frustrated with our lives when we have it so much better? Read this and share it. It may just change your life for the better.

http://www.thesmartlocal.com/read/this-is-why-young-singaporeans-think-their-lives-suckOur generation has it far better than any other but we struggle daily to find fulfilment and happiness, far more than the generations before us. Here's why.
comments:
I think this applies to most of the first world, not just Singapore.$$Let's deviate from the 'millenials are all overentitled brats' cliche and get realistic. 

The baby boomers had it much much easier that millenials. The global economy grew at an unprecendented level during their time, and that rising tide carried SG (and as a result the baby boomers) to a level of prosperity that they *think* they worked for harder than other generations to attain.

With just a degree (or even diploma in some cases), you could get a decent home for 5 figures (and watch it's value get marked up through evaluation to half a million dollars by "voting wisely"), afford a car, several kids, and the cost of living in general was incredibly manageable. 

And yet people have the balls to say millenials "have it far better than any other generation." How misled and fallacious.$$Gotta draw some snakes and ladders in there too$$I think you need to highlight the WaitButWhy original posting and the link a bit more noticeably!

message+desc:
Where is it? 
CCP, Manila

What is it? 
The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) is the premiere showcase of the arts in the country. Founded in 1969 under the Marcos regime, it still continues to hold the most celebrated and award-winning plays from around the world. At night, it's therapeutic to watch the fountain lightshow ‚Äî a colorful oasis by the side of the main road, in the middle of a busy metro.

How to get there: 
Fly into Manila through one of more than 30 international airlines. You can also fly in from any major Philippine city.

Or take a bus from any major city in Luzon.

Or take a boat from any major Philippine port.

Fun Fact: 
In the main lobby of the National Theater, you'll notice three large Capiz-shell chandeliers hanging from the third-floor ceiling. They symbolize the three main geographical divisions of the Philippines ‚Äî Luzon, Visayas and Mindanao.

Photo by/Headline by: 
George Tapan/Donna Dimayuga
comments: I would love to go there$$this is CULTURAL CENTER OF THE PHILIPPINES(CCP).

message+desc:
The province of Capiz is known for its gorgeous shells and amazing seafood. But did you know that it also houses a number of caves, a black sand beach and the largest bell in Southeast Asia? Click to know more! 
 
http://itsmorefuninthephilippines.com/capiz-2/...
comments:
Capiz... my Dad's home province, where he was born and have grown up as a young man.

Capiz is one of the four provinces of the Panay Island in the Philippines.  The other three are Aklan, Antique and Iloilo ‚Äî all four (including Capiz) are in the Western Visayas Region.

The people of Panay played the most significant role in resisting the Japanese during World War II.  In fact, Panay is signified in the Philippine National Flag.

My dad and one of his younger brothers were guerillas during World War II, and were United States Army Scouts during the same war.

message+desc:
If you want to have experiences to wear Kimono, eat Japanese food and see old towns in Kanto region, Kawagoe in Saitame pref. is one of the areas. It takes about 30 min. from Ikebukuro, about 60 min. from Shibuya and about 80 min. from Yokohama by train.
 You could enjoy a stroll around Kurazukuri Zone (old storehouse zone) with its traditional atmosphere and architecture.
Rental kimonos are available and on Kawagoe Kimono Day, the 18th of every month, some shops have special services to customers wearing kimono or yukata!  Also, it is famous for sweet potatoes, so there are various types of Japanese-style confection and snacks made with sweet potatoes.
Try them and enjoy Kawagoe!
 
 More details: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/saitama/kawagoe.html
comments: Been there. .not bad. An hour train ride from seibu shinjuku station$$Is there any hotels around the area?$$I hope if visit Japan in next time, will go to Kawagoe.$$I live here near the Kawagoe-city.

message+desc:
Where is it?
Coron, Palawan

How to Get There:
Fly from Manila to Busuanga, then transfer to a van bound for Coron.

What is it?
Coron has a coral garden in its shallow waters and even a World War II Japanese shipwreck that has become home to all sorts of tropical fish! It's the perfect dive site if you want to get into underwater photography.

Fun Fact:
You can also go night-diving in Coron - a great experience for amateur divers!

Photo taken by Bob Whorton
comments: Very long to see huge.

message+desc:
Goa - Pearl of the Orient, Beach Capital of India

Goa, situated on the west coast of India, is one of the most delightful states in India. Formerly a Portuguese colony, it is endowed with variety of attractions, like palm pronged beaches, miles of golden sands, lush green country-side, an incredible mosaic of cultural heritage, magnificent churches, temples, forts and monuments and a unique cultural synthesis of the east and west. 

With its tropical climate, Goa is a tourist‚Äôs destination for all seasons. Goa‚Äôs cities are impressively individual. The capital, Panjim (Panaji), for many, hast the edge over many cities in the country.Replete with colonial architecture, the city is known for its vibrancy that attains its pinnacle in the annual Goa Carnival festival. 

- See more at: http://www.incredibleindia.org/travel/destination/goa
comments: One of the most beautiful bathing beaches in India ...$$Is it looks so beautiful there

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Angono, Rizal

What is it like? 
Water is so central to Angono life that during the town's yearly festival, fishermen hang their catch near the image of the town's patron saint. Of course, St. Clement is also the patron saint of fishermen. Afterwards, the image, the fish and the fishermen get on a large boat and parade down the Angono River.

Fun Fact: 
Angono is also known for its higantes ‚Äî colorful oversized paper-mache effigies.

Photo by/Author: 
Benjamin D. Flores/Nikki Golez
comments: The Artist Paradise, Higantes üëç. I was born and raised there. üòä

Gather your squad and challenge yourselves at the vertigo climbing wall, The Cliff when you are there! There are a total of 10 climbing lanes of various difficulty levels, ranging from  10 metres to 15metres!

We tried the following activities:
1.      Snowfall Experience
2.      Sport Climbing at The Cliff
3.      Skiing and Snow Boarding at SportsQuest Snow Academy

Prices range from $12 to $100.

Address: 21 Jurong Town Hall Rd, Singapore 609433
Opening hours: 10am to 6pm everyday

Director: Audrey Faith I Models: Russ Tan and Angela Lau

message+desc:
Let's all send our #postcardsfromparadise to Ringo Starr on July 7!

Today, thousands of postcards from the Philippines have already been sent out to Beatles drummer Ringo Starr in response to his call to send #postcardsfromparadise.
 
In support of Ely Buendia and Esquire Philippines‚Äô efforts to bring Ringo back to our shores, let‚Äôs continue to share beautiful photos of our country with Ringo and the rest of the world via social media!
 
And on July 7, 2015 (Tuesday), we invite everyone to send Ringo these #postcardsfromparadise to show him some love from the Philippines on his birthday!  To learn more on how you can participate, watch the video! 
 
#itsmorefuninthephilippines #visitPH2015

They were very upset cause they were bashed at the airport: They said, Madadala daw sila ng malaking paputok sa susunod na pagbalik nila sa Pilipinas. message+desc:
Gua Madu got its name from the numerous bee hives found in the cave that produce honey. It is believed that Gua Madu is the cave that has the largest collection of bee hives in the state. Visitors can still view the hives made by bees since tens of years ago.

Get to know more from the following blog by Zabidi Ishar:
http://magakhmer.blogspot.com/2011/08/gua-madu-draws-tourists-to-gua-musang.html
comments: For the best experience, take KTM train from Kuala Lumpur to go to Gua Musang, a small town near Gua Madu

From April 20th to May 5th, ‚ÄúKakunodate Cherry Blossom Festival‚Äù is held!
Kakunodate is a historic town in Akita pref. It is remain of Japanese castle town. There are many Samurai residences, and some of these are owned by the descendants of Samurais. You can also find out how Samurai lived by visiting some residences open for visitors. Quiet and historical atmosphere surrounded by nature creates the elegance of this town. It may also be interesting to use hotels and restaurants that are Samurai-period styled.
It‚Äôll take 3hrs 15mins from Tokyo to JR Kakunodate Station by Akita Shinkansen, or you can get there from Akita airport by the Airport Liner. 

More information about Kakunodate:
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/akita/kakunodate.html

message+desc:
Where is it?
Espa√±a, Manila 

How to Get There:
"Fly into Manila through one of more than 30 international airlines. You can also fly in from any major Philippine city.

Or take a bus from any major city in Luzon.

Or take a boat from any major Philippine port."

What is it?
University of Sto. Tomas is one of the largest Catholic universities in the world. It's also the Philippines‚Äôs oldest. Founded on April 28, 1611, the university boasts providing more than 400 years of quality education in the Philippines.

Fun Fact:
The university has its share of remarkable alumni, including four Philippine presidents: Manuel Quezon, Sergio Osme√±a, Jose Laurel, and Diosdado Macapagal.

Photo by / Headline by:
George Tapan / Brandon Dollente

message+desc:
Now it is getting cooler and cooler in Japan and it must be a good season to go to ONSEN, hot springs !

Noboribetsu Onsen in Hokkaido is one of the popular hot spring spots in Japan.
The first charm is the abundance of hot spring water (1 ton in a day!) and it is called ‚Äúdepartment store of hot spring."
At Noboribetsu Onsen, you can see explosion crater called ‚ÄúJigoku-dani‚Äù (means hell-valley). You can hike there and feel the great power of nature that springs Onsen.
Also, you will be welcomed by Oni (demon) when you get there.

Access; It takes less than 1 hour from Chitose Airport or about an hour from Sapporo.

More Information:
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/hokkaido/noboribetu.html
http://www.noboribetsu-spa.jp/?lang=en
Photos by Noboribetsu Tourism Association

Chocolate Hills, Bohol

What is it like? 
You‚Äôll find these huge mounds that look like chocolate kisses scattered throughout the towns of Carmen, Batuan and Sagbayan in Bohol. Their numbers are estimated to be around 1,268 to 1,776.

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila to Tagbilaran.

Or take the Roll-On Roll-Off (RORO) ferry from Cebu to Tagbilaran.

Or take a boat from Cebu or any of the major cities in Mindanao to Tagbilaran.

Fun Fact: 
Many myths try to explain the creation of the Chocolate Hills. In one of the legends, a giant fell in love with a human being. When she died, the giant cried heavy tears that formed the hills.

Photo by/Headline by: 
Engr. Alan T. Manansala SCJP, PMP/Brandon Dollente
comments: There's no place like home.

message+desc:
Traveling around the Philippines? 8list.ph gives you 8 essential things to remember to make your trip memorable and More Fun! Click on the link to read about them and share the tips with your friends!

http://8list.ph/backpacking-in-the-philippines/Travel around the Philippines like a true Filipino.
comments:
We'd like to share our own GREEN TRAVEL TIPS for SUSTAINABLE TOURISM in the Philippines! It will be more fun for the FUTURE GENERATIONS!  http://sstdi.org/2012/10/04/green-travel-tips/$$Seems that pic no.2 is a scene from thailand. Overall great article.$$did the sea urchins thing :) did taste nice at that moment :)$$8 Things You Shouldn't Forget To Do When Traveling Around The Philippines.

1. Don't for get to get ripped-off my the Taxi Drivers at the Airports (MNL and Clk mostly.) The same with Trike Drivers at Tourist spots. It may not be much for you. But that amount of money could be as much as some poor guy breaking his back in a rice field.

2. Don't forget the food Totally SUCKS; Caveat the street Chicken or some BBQ.
If you can't make you‚Äôre own food there, ask expats where to find decent food.

3. Don't learn the Language; you'll be wasting your time, unless you stay in one place or with a group of friends. There's three different Languages here -- plus English. English is the 'common' language. If you don't know English, learn that one.

4. If you miss home, go to a mall... Half the Malls here are very nice... The other half are like something you'd see in  developed countries 40-years ago.

5. If you make new friends, realize they share an OZ of beer with you, they'd expect 16 OZs in return.

6. 'Keep it Clean.' There's trash and shit all over the place here... but, us foreigners don't really litter anyway.

7. Support the locals, but, not the Tourist Scammers (Taxi, Street People, and whatnot.) You can go to the local Sari-sari (small, rustic, 'convinces' store.) and buy what you can from there. They're regular families working, trying to make a honest living in a place that is difficult to do so. 

8. SMILE... Like many country‚Äôs in SE Asia. The here people like you... I think because you are different and come from a different place??? Isn‚Äôt that why you like them and are there???

      -Uncle Frank$$easily said but not practice ah,!

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Baler, Aurora

What is it like? 
Baler's Cobra reef is a top destination for surfers. While Ampere beach is a favorite of photographers ‚Äì located 20km from the surfing town. The beach is frequented for its distinct sea stacks and the large smooth boulders that make up its shore.

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila to Baler.

Or take a bus bound for Baler from Pasay.

Fun Fact: 
Okotan Cave in Ampere beach is where residents go to forecast the weather. Waves hitting the shoreline cave create a booming sound. Its intensity determines how bad incoming weather will be.

Photo by/Headline by: 
Caloy Llamas/Rachel Teotico
comments: Will you take me there?

Its the 1st time my son meet his Daddy or call him Appa  HeRu Namza  as like korean said üòä 

@gamcheonvillage is one of place many story 4 years ago
1st time i meet him üíèüíë and now... in 2016 after had our guardian "Baby Gibran" we come back. üë£‚ù§

we love so much this place many inspiring for us so many colours like our life.

 #MyVisitKoreaStory$$#MyVisitKoreaStory from July 2016 is a different kind of travel story because it is not about nature, the grand palaces or the unique food in Korea. This photo is inside the venue of a concert I attended in the Olympic Stadium. It was a very memorable experience to be joining the fan chants while EXO performs. During this trip I also got to know fans from U.S., Australia, Japan and France and knowing that Korean pop music has inspired them enough too to make a trip to Seoul. This trip made me see the intense K-pop culture of the youth while still being friendly towards foreign fans. This was a very different trip for me because I used to make trips to immerse myself into Korea's nature, busy shopping streets, art cafes and grand palaces. This was a trip that made me closer to my fandom and also fulfilled my wish of watching my favorite K-pop group right there in their home country. Truly, a beautiful memory I will always keep with me.$$My first trip to Korea with my daughter's! It was a dream come true. I was born in Korea and went back when I was little. I wanted to go back with my mother but she passed away in 2008. I always told my daughter's that we would go to Korea and it finally happened this year.  It would be awesome to go back and see the rest of the country of my mother. #MyVisitKoreaStory  May 2016$$#MyVisitKoreaStory Having to immerse in their local culture I decided to try out their street food stalls which is really fun. Seeing the friendly lady cooking for me and the grilled aromatic of the fresh seafood and meat just simply makes my stomach growling really loud which lucky the Locals beside me are too busy chatting away.$$Photo was taken when autumn season in November 2015 that was my last day for trip of korea. Feel like at home. I am fall in love with korea at the first sight when i saw a drama Autumn in My Heart. This country is so beautiful and makes me always wanna go there. I will waiting for my lovely Knight and go back there to lock our love forever.
#NamsanSeoulTower
#MyVisitKoreaStory$$I am from Indonesia, a tropic country where it has only two seasons: dry season and wet season. Therefore, I have a dream willing to experience other seasons like spring, winter and autumn in different country. Then I choose South Korea for my autumn experience. Here, I went there on last October 2015. I visited Soeraksan and Nami Island. Those places were fullfiled with yellow ginkgo and red maple trees where the leaves falling everywhere. It was definitely beautiful. I never see maple and ginkgo before because they doesn't grow in Indonesia, and finally I touched them. Love it! #MyVisitKoreaStory$$I want to participate this event. I has uploaded my photo not sure that I'm do it the correct way or not cos I didn't see my post at Korea Tourism Organization webpage, kindly let me know I'm successful posted.$$Samcheongdong Hanok definitely caught my attention the moment I stepped on there. That place is simply picturesque and while in pictures it may not look interesting but trust me, the moment you reach there you really want to take as many pictures as possible and keep all the memories forever with you because that place just looks so beautiful and stunning. #MyVisitKoreaStory$$I was in Gyeongbokgung Palace back in this May and it's one of the most important and beautiful site to visit while in Seoul. The view inside the palace just looks stunning and it's pretty big place too walk around too. The construction and roof tiles is definitely unique and artistic for the ancient palaces. There is also a museum and there are just so many things to see and of course many pictures to take too :D. I'm looking forward to visit Gyeongbokgung again in another season during winter when the view is completely different from Summer. #MyVisitKoreaStory$$#MyVisitKoreaStory This meal at Jinokhwa Halmae Wonjo Dakhanmari is situated at an alley at Dongdaemun (ÎèôÎåÄÎ¨∏) never failed to erase off my memory for the best delicious chicken pot that can be so exciting with the variety of condiments, kimchi, rice cakes and noodles that surprisingly from a plain chicken hotpot that can magically turn into the best Chicken Hot pot that I ever tasted in my whole life. It was the most memorable dish for me and certainly I been craving and wanting to go back there to indulge again.  #KoreaTourismOrganizationVisitKorea$$#MyVisitKoreaStory from October 2015

Autumn is my favorite season and it is unfortunate that we don't experience it in the Philippines. That's why on my first solo trip during autumn in Seoul, I took the time to visit Seoraksan located in the nearby province of Seokcho. I reached this beautiful mountain via the Dongbu bus line. Upon reaching the foot of the mountain where the trails begin, the orange and yellow leaves of the trees of Seorak are already visible. There are a lot of hiking trails and you can choose from which way to begin by the signages. I went to Biryong falls, Myeonsangil path, path to Biseondae rocks and Sinheungsa temple. Although I was not equipped enough to go to Ulsanbawi where the famous rigged stony trail is found on the way to the summit. It was a very manageable day hike for my first time hiking the trails alone. The tension bridge in the picture leads to a falls located deeper into the hiking trail. I plan to be back in spring and explore the nearby places around Seokcho.

message+desc:
Over 400years history, Snow dome Festival in Akita!

In wintertime, many of Japan's snow-related customs can still be found in the Yokote area. The area is famous for the "Kamakura"(snow dome) festival where children gather in constructed snow houses. The water god is honored in Kamakura and this festival has history of over 400 years. In the evening, children offer sweet nonalcoholic rice wine and sweets. More than 100 snow domes are built in the city during the event.

Akita Pref.

http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/akita/index.html

http://www.akitafan.com/en/index.html
comments: very cold what a beautiful view

message+desc: The summer holiday season is upon us and as a result, some stores in Dongdaemun Market will be closed for 3-10 days. Don't miss your shopping fix; check the schedule here: http://bit.ly/TamZUB
comments: Going to Korea on mid September. Want to know what season that is in Korea. Also please recommend best places to visit. Thanks!$$It will be autumn. I have holidayed in Korea in September for the past 2 years. Booked all our accommodation online 8 weeks before we left home - no problems anywhere. It is a wonderful country and has an amazing, train, subway and bus system. There is a lot to see and do around Seoul. We stayed in Myeongdong area which is great and not far from Insadong (favourite shopping centre for tourists). Make sure you visit KNTO office in Seoul - lots of information and staff extremely helpful. Friom Seoul take a bus to Andong and visit the Hahoe Village and Folk Village. On to Gyeongju another very interesting place - lots of history and tombs of the Shilla monarchs, also temples. On to Busan then take train to Daegu. From Daegu you can take a bus to Hainsa Temple and see Tripitaka Koreana - the world's most ancient storage facility of Buddhist scriptures - fascinating. Jeonju another interesting city and you can wander around the Hanok village all day, lots of tea houses and craft shops. Be sure to try bibimbap - specialty of that area. Suwan  is a must - Hwaseon Fortress - lots of walking.  When in Seoul I suggest you apply for one of the goodwill guides through KNTO - they are excellent and will take you to places of interest.  Have a great holiday - I just love Korea.$$miss dongdaemun..been there last 2 weeks

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Bantayan Beach, Cebu

What is it? 
Bantayan once served as a Spanish base against Moro invasions. That's why a walk around can transport you centuries back. You can see traces of its heritage in the old Spanish-era houses and dilapidated fort ruins. Mangroves and palm trees line the shores of Sugar Beach, Paradise Beach and Virgin Island.

How to get there: 
Fly into Cebu from Hongkong, Singapore, Narita, Incheon, or any major Philippine city.

Or take a bus to Cebu from either Dumaguete or Bacolod. Or take your car via a Roll-On Roll-Off (RORO) ferry.

Or take a boat to Cebu from Manila or any major city in Visayas and Mindanao.

Then take a bus or shuttle from Cebu City to Hagnaya, then a ferry to the port of Sta. Fe.

Fun Fact: 
This island's watchtowers gave it the name ‚ÄúBantayan sa Hari‚Äù (Watchtower of the King). This was later shortened to ‚ÄúBantayan,‚Äù the name it's known as today.

Photo by/Headline by: 
George Tapan/Donna Dimayuga
comments: I love this place. It can take all my stress away.$$were very proud being a BANTAYANON$$Years back...not too far ago...I slept in its sands...waves waking me with the bright shining moon on the heavens...Bantayan.$$I love my home land bantayan and I'm proud to be a batayanon.$$We've been there, it is a beautiful Island and the people are tourist friendly. We are planning to go back sometime this year.$$I miss it everyday, not a day goes by I don't wish we were all there...$$Another must see place!  Thanks for sharing!$$Soon im there!!! With my mahal ko!!!$$im proud of bantayan...my relatives are from bantayan..

message+desc:
We tried something very different in this week's vlog. We looked at a problem most Singaporeans don't even know exists - littering. 

We leave our empty drinks in our movie cinemas seats. Random tissue papers are always floating on MRT seats. We choke drains with our cigarrates. And we don't even think twice about it. Because garbage on the street is better than in our pockets. 

Some of us have become so entitled that we say we "help" the cleaners by giving them a "job" to do. That's when you know something is wrong. Maybe that's why we don't return our food trays.

I'm guilty for being part of those groups at parties who don't clean up well, leaving cleaners with a ton of extra work to do. It seems normal when no one seems to care. But I'm not going to act that way again. 

Let us know if you want to do something about littering by leaving a comment or by sharing this video so more people see it.

Follow us on YouTube. We upload a new video every weekday.
https://www.youtube.com/thesmartlocal

Featuring: 
Thomas Blysk Kopankiewicz

This post was brought to you by TSL. :p

Business Enquiries: 
hello@thesmartlocal.com
comments:
kudos to TheSmartLocal.com for creating this content. keep on producing content to create social awareness on issues that truly matter :)$$It's all about personal values. Never about giving others a job to do. We put everything in the bin, it speaks volume about us as a society. I would want to be part of a society who knows basic respect to the environment. We can't save it... at least respect it.$$I wonder if the schools still run campaigns like picking up litter. During my time as a primary school kid, schools held campaigns to encourage everyone to pick up litter we see and drop them into bins. It used to be so normal to be walking midway through, stopping to pick up litter in our way then dropping them into bins. These days I don't see that anymore, even I have stopped doing that. Can't even rmb the last time I did that üòÇ$$I'm very proud to say that I clear my tray..(IKEA is the right place to sit and watch people. They eat chicken wings like they've never eaten chicken wings for ages then leave the bones and plates on the table and walk awayüò°üò°). Actually I have sweet wrappers in my handbag coz sometimes I can't find a bin on the streets. 
I want a clean cinema, clean table at hawker ctrs, food courts etc....every little help goes a long way.$$I feel a lot of people after the have eaten or drank, the suddenly become handicap!!!!!!$$Collect all the rubbish over a certain area and have a commuters day where they can be aware$$as long as we are a "lazy" community this problem will exist$$littering here has been endemic for decades, you speak poorly of your audience by assuming their ignorance$$super agree on this. esp the smokers... always flicking cigg butts everywhere. smoking is your personal choice but pls dont litter!!$$The empty drink cans, plastic bottles and even cigarette packs can be recycled instead...$$What you have been nagging about everyday Shawn Lim$$We don't run campaigns like we used to. üòÄ

message+desc:
Bangon, Pinas! The folks at the Department of Tourism and the Tourism Promotions Board have created the Bangon Tours Project. Visit any of the places listed and help rebuild the lives of the survivors of typhoon Haiyan. Indeed, the best time to go around the country is NOW! 

http://asia.etbnews.com/178217/philippines-bangon-tourism/Domestic tourism campaign to assist Filipino communities.
comments:
"The Philippines‚Äô private sector has been encouraged to voluntarily share a percentage of their net income derived from the Bangon Tours, to help fund local foundations and charitable institutions."  

Hmmm, I'd rather directly help the affected communities.  (Too much potential for others to just take advantage of this situation for profit, I must say).  There are so many non-profit/ service organizations on the ground, and the need is so great and will be for long-term recovery.  That's where I would direct my money and my efforts to help.

message+desc:
[GIVEAWAY] Experience South East Asia's FIRST 8K 3D Resolution Dome Theatre at Omni-Theatre. Immerse yourself in a 360 degree cinematic experience filled with flying spaceships and terrifying dinosaurs in the 23 meter wide dome screen in super high quality in both 2D & 3D formats!

Omni-Theatre is giving away 5 pairs of tickets to 5 lucky winners worth $28 each!

All you have to do is follow these simple steps:
1. Simply like and share this video on Facebook.
2. Comment here telling us why you want to win.

Contest ends on the 14th of Feburary 2016. Good Luck!:)

Omni Theater - Science Centre Singapore
Address: 21 Jurong Town Hall, Singapore 609433
Opening Hours: 12pm - 6pm

Find out more here: https://www.omnitheatre.com.sg/Omni-Theatre-Singapore-Home

Never want to miss a post by us again?
Like TheSmartLocal.com and choose "Follow All Posts!"

Director: Russ Tan
Models: Russ, Angela Lau and  Ria Chia Cai Yun

message+desc:
‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know how it‚Äôs possible, but I have been both hardened AND softened by my experience here,‚Äù writes American traveler Nathan Allen about his travels in the PH. Read his straightforward, honest assessment of the country and let us know your thoughts! 

http://www.idreamedofthis.com/2013/11/27/what-i-really-think-of-the-philippines/Heartfelt (and hilarious) observations after living in the Philippines for a year.
comments:
I'm not confused. I love it here, retired in Cebu for a year & half now, did take me a while to just slow down after 35 years in San Francisco Bay Area, have been all over Cebu Bohol Negros Oriental and the best Palawan. Yes poverty is pervasive but the Filopino people are the friendliest most humble on the planet.$$Wonderful article and very honest about these remarkable people. I have been blessed to have married a beautiful Phillipino women ha and family. She is an incredible wife. I plan on retirement in the fils. Slow my life down and love and support my aswa with all my heart.$$I've been to Manila and Cebu. I loved them both and especially fell in love with the joy of the people who live here. üòç$$This is just garbage written by a woolly-brained American liberal wracked with misplaced white guilt. The Philippines is fine. Happiness isn't about material wealth at all--though wealth is great! 

And the wonderful thing is, the economy in the Philippines is about to boom. Many many people are going to experience so many good things very soon there. They have finally solved the only real problem they ever had: Corrupt thieves posing as politicians.$$I've also been there for a month living with the people living in the privince and witnessed some city boys and girls begging for money on every corner in the cites. Yes people in the province were different. I heard they emphasize happiness over financial richness several times. Meanwhile I got some chances to talk privately with the young girls (not the boys) then I noticed some different inner sides and desires. They mostly said that they wanted to live in a bigger house and hoped that they would be able to go abroad to live a richer life with modern environment. Briefly speaking they said they want to live in a more modern style than now. Of course they said they are happy with the current life with their family members and relatives but deep inside I found that they yearn for some different lives as in the TV dramas or in some films. Happiness is indeed something relative. If the girls hadn't seen any more developed coutries and lives first or secondhand they would be perfectly content with their recent lives. But the opposite is the case for those girls living in the 21th century. I come to an conclusion which is half subjective and half objective that people in PH have two inner sides in one of which they are really happy despite of lack of money and in another they hope for a better more modern life now.$$This is just purely an opinion from a foreigner who is just merely comparing Phil and his home country- just his personal unsolicited observation. In anyway doesn't represent the Filipino culture as a whole. Indeed Westerners have high standard of living but working at least 16 hrs a day with two or three different jobs just to be able to pay their taxes, bills and credit cards for a lifetime!!! I still choose the Filipino way.$$Was in the Philippines two times now. Loved it and plan to come back. Have friends there and i see how hard their life is! As in any country in the world there is light and darkness....till now i had no bad experiences and hope the next trip will be as wonderful as before. Im thankful to read about other peoples trips and how they see things. Looking forword to go back and see more places!$$Thank you for being true in your observation and expressing your feelings about our country and I'm glad you saw the good and bad side of it with an open mind and an open heart....I applaud you for your post and you are more than welcome to come and visit our beautiful country again and again...God Speed$$I've been to Philippines two times now. I love it! I'm married to Filipina and one day would love to retire there. Very good article!$$The Philippines is my most favourite destination. The beauty of Bohol and friendly people makes me excited to come back soon. I have also encouraged my friends not to look past it with so much to explore, but no balut for me !!!$$Nice, honest and candid of Mr Allen's stay in the Phil. 

Thank you for both the great and challenging stories you shares. Visit Phil again. 

Ps: this article was written three years ago.$$Nathan Allen is like Kyle Jennermann or more popularly known as "Kulas" who's a Canadian and loves it in the Philippines so much. Thank you guys for loving my country!$$I pretty much agree with you, on everything. Even though,  I've been going to the Philippines for the last 10 years, and my wife is from Luzon, I really enjoy the warmth of the Filipinos!
They are all about family, which, as Americans we have seemed to have forgotten, this.
I can't wait to retire in 6 years!$$dear tourism phl, The Philippines you might want to take a look and do something about him being declared as persona non grata in sorsogon. üòí its not fair to him when he genuinely loved the philippines üôÇ

http://www.idreamedofthis.com/2016/05/22/nathan-allen-tells-truth-gets-banned-attacked-by-pinoy-travel-bloggers/$$So proud Filipino here. Reading this from the beginning till the end. Teary eyed when done. Tsada magpuyo dri no? Salamat sa pag appreciate sa Pilipinas. God bless you more. Take care always.$$The parts about America are somewhat true. I never felt I needed to buy a Starbucks to fit in, maybe I am different but if you can't afford it then don't buy it. Many Americans agree with me and don't feel pressure like this author feels. If you don't want it don't buy it.$$This guy really doesn't understand piany, he judges from a perspective of America, and mo own experience's there seeing poverty, seeing  poor helping the poor, and people with job's help as well, hindi one can judge a country from a year! Only being born and raised there, to know the truth, that's the true story of a The culture dynamic there north and south.$$Nothing new here, all Americans are confused! üòÇ
Poverty, take a look at your own country!!!
The poverty is just hidden better in the USA.$$Adam Marshall you should read this. And I mean read, not just skimming it. Maybe helps you learn more/understand things about the Philippines.$$Sunnybelle - follow the link and read the article. When I read this, it was as if I was traveling. :D$$Quite an impressive page. :) :) You did a good job in describing our culture here. I hope you can go back and observe/explore other areas/islands of my country that remains untouched and they are just waiting to be seen. Next time, maybe you can visit the Eastern side of the country, wherein they have different language and somewhat different cultures, not to mention good places to visit too. :) :) Cheers!$$Yea...i dont think hes confused. He has several good points. The people there are happy. In fact its also known as the country where everyone has a smile. The country needs work...but as far as a good country to live in...ive done a lot of research. Its a great place for an american...Australian..             European..to live.$$We are a nation of extremes, ironies, and contradictions. This article just reflects all those things that make this nation a peculiar but unforgettable place. My compliments to the writer.$$I read all the pages of your research actually Filipinos have different cultures and beliefs but one thijng i assure you Filipinos are hospital,friendly people..$$I cried again reading your piece!!!!!!!! Hope you would consider going back someday!  I am 100% sure all your Filipino families all over the Philippines are yearning for your return!  I would love to know what your perspective is now with the newly elected president and his administration... Have a wonderful day and thanks for the birthday greet yesterday!!!! üòòüòçüòä

message+desc: Traveling in Seoul by subway just became a little easier for foreign tourists! http://english.visitkorea.or.kr/enu/FU/FU_EN_15.jsp?cid=1522312Public transit pass for foreign tourists launched
comments:
Can it be used in other cities too like the T-Money card?$$Sorry Adrian, it can only be used for the Seoul metropolitian area subway lines.$$what the difference betweem M-Money & T-Money??$$That's even better...looking for it during my summer trip this year :D$$There must be some mistake with the price?!? Who will take more than 10 rides a day (roughly equalling the value of a day pass) and also given the fact that there are no busses included...am I missing something?
Its so bad, especially for Koreans, that there is no proper daily, weekly or monthly tickets for public transportation in Seoul. Ticket fares seem to be cheap, but it adds up, if you have to commute every day..$$As excited as I am to see Seoul putting effort into doing something good for foreigners, I am inclined to agree with Paul. As someone who doesn't live in Seoul, but likes to go for weekends and holidays, I cannot see myself ever making this pass to be financially efficient. It seems like a LOT of money. If it were up to me, I'd lower the price to 5,000 won a day, and lower the number of possible rides to 10 or 15 a day (not including line transfers, those should not be counted.) I have NEVER known a foreigner to take more then 10 subway trips a day, let alone meet the maximum number of 20.$$Hmm it does seem a little expensive for a day pass - I love the Metro in Seoul - but the best way to see Seoul is walk around its amazing what you miss between stations! 20,000won on a T Money card can  last about a week for me!$$Mufizah- The M-pass allows you to make up to twenty trips in 1 day for 10,000 won, so it is ideal for travelers planning to take a large number of trips on the subway in one day because it gives a savings over the normal rate if you take more than 10 subway rides in a single day. However, it can't be used for buses or in other metropolitian areas, or recharged like a T-money card.$$I love Seoul subway !!!!! Nvr thought it will be easy till I 've tried it out last yr ;)$$That card is way to expensive. Most cities have cards that make up there value with only 3-5 rides. This one takes more than 10 to be worth it. Don't buy if coming to Seoul. $$...So not really a good option unless you plan to spend you day on the subway lol!$$Even then it might be cheaper to take the t-money, just take line nr. 1 all day :)$$Great idea and a huge help for travellers! Is there a similar thing for other cities in Korea?$$Hi Travel Bug! This is just for the Seoul subway.$$i already try it..it's fun & easy too..hehe..luv to try again next time$$I think this is actually a great idea!  This pass if for tourists coming into Seoul, a ride on the train from Incheon to Seoul Station is about 4,000 won one way and then you are forgetting  that base fare is 900 won with a card, and it increases as you travel over distance.  And think about tourists would don't necessarily realize that a destination is much closer walking than taking the subway for one stop?  I know people would rather feel safe knowing that they can take the subway for one stop and exactly know where they are when they exit the subway.

20 rides are day for 10,000 won is quite generous actually, since 10,000 won for Seoulites is only about 8 - 10 rides...$$Hi Ana! It is a day pass costing 10,000 won and is good for up to 20 rides in one day. So, as other people have commented, it saves you money only if you take more than eleven standard 900-won subway rides in one day.$$but 20 rides in a day? is it possible ? to around Seoul in a day ? but if p er ride about 4000 one way...hhmm will think about it :-), i think Beijing subway is more more cheap hehehe$$if i'm not mistaken,this what i've read from the guesthouse website.It takes about 53 minutes from Incheon airport to Seoul Station and the fair is 3,700won(Non-Stop train ; 13,300won)$$This is a great idea.

message+desc:
Fruit picking in summer!
There are several orchards in Japan offering fruit-picking experiences to the public on a pay by weight, per piece or all-you-can-eat basis. In Japan, it is one of the popular weekend activities with friends or families with small children.
Currently, peaches, blueberries, watermelons, plums, melons are in season. Tourist can certainly experience this, and it is a great opportunity to taste fresh local ‚Äúmade in Japan‚Äù fruits.
Day tour is also available, and you can find the schedule and location on line.
For further information: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/attractions/dining/food/jfood_11.html
http://jnto.org.au/adventure-outdoors/fruit-picking/
Search for Tours and Activities: http://japan-tours.jnto.go.jp/eng/index.php
comments:
Noted. Reza let's try this one too :)$$Awesome ^^ I'd like to have that too where I live ^^

That is a really nice kind of thing to do ^^$$That grapes... Lim Kim Chye

message+desc:
Today is #ipchun (ÏûÖÏ∂ò)! Ipchun is one of the twenty-four solar terms that marks coming of üå±springüå± according to the lunar calendar! In the past, it was a custom to post papers with words that bear wishes of good luck and abundance on the main door or pillars on ipchun day as people greeted spring into the year. 
If you happen to be on a #VisitKorea trip this time of the year, take a closer look, especially at #Hanok_Villages and you might find doors with writings just like in the photo. Take a photoüì∑ if you find one and let us know where you found it in the comments below!üëá
comments:
Yup... saw this at Bukchon (ÂåóÊùëÔºâ
Of course, we understand the good meanings behind the couplets. However, out of curiosity, why's the paper used white and not red. Is white an auspicious colour in Korea? Appreciate your kind insights on the matter.

For us in Singapore, Ipchun (Á´ãÊò• - Li Chun) likewise, signifies the start of Spring. What happens on this day is indicative of ones wellbeing for the rest of the year.... Therefore banking money into ones bank account signifies (hopefully) abundance and wealth.

Just some cross-cultural sharing! 
„äóÔ∏è Happy Ipchun!! üå∏$$Found this at namsangol hanok village! And I took a pic there too!

message+desc:
Where is it?
Sunset Boulevard, Dipolog

How to Get There:
Fly into Zamboanga from Manila, Cebu or Davao.

Or take a boat to Zamboanga from Manila.

What is it?
Sunset Boulevard is a great spot to witness ‚Äì what else ‚Äì breathtaking sunsets. While enjoying the view, you might see other people catching their breath too. The boulevard is a popular spot for people trying to get fit.

Fun Fact:
As soon as the sun sets, the barbecue grills open. They offer a variety of choices. You can have pork and chicken meat, or pork liver and chicken feet if you're feeling more adventurous.

Photo by / Headline by:
Eamarie M. Gilayo / Brandon Dollente

message+desc:
[New Guide] 16 Malaysian Slangs - Here's a guide for our Malaysian readers! 

Even Singaporeans may not understand all words on this list!

From "Leng Zai" to "Perasan", our Malaysian friends sure have a cool way of expressing themselves, which is similar but still very different to how Singaporeans talk.

SAME SAME BUT DIFFERENT. Ok Thailand guide next? Haha!

http://www.thesmartlocal.com/read/malaysian-slangIf you can't understand all the 16 Malaysian Slang on this list, you're probably not a true blue Malaysian. Here is why our language is awesome.
comments:
I beg to differ and say that most Singaporeans DO understand most of these words, as based on demographics, it is likely that majority of the words you cited would actually have originated from Singapore.  The only slang new to me is "Perasan",  and I agree that is probably Malaysian slang. "Blanja" is as pronounced and open for discussion as to its origin.
Interesting that you saw a need to subsume Singaporean slang as Malaysian slang. 
I'm sure if u asked around, u will find many truly unique instances of Malaysian slang, no need to claim Singaporean slang as only your own. Singaporeans are fine with sharing their slang (that's part of the fun!) but do give/share credit where credit is due, yah?
I wish u success in your research of Malaysian slang.
And I'm secretly a cat too. üò∏$$As a S'porean, the only 2 I couldn't understand are 1. No.16 -Perasan and 2. No.9- Ioll (I-alls)...

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Ifugao, Luzon

What is it like? 
According to the Cordillera myth, the Ifugao people were created from Wigan, the god of Skyworld. Legend has it that Wigan gave the rice-terrace farming Ifugaos the first sacred rice. It's believed to be of the ipugo (rice of god) variety, which amazingly still flourishes despite certain the harsh conditions of the mountain ranges.

Fun Fact: 
There are more than 20 different cultural dances in this region alone. Each dance is specifically used to celebrate a family occasion or community milestone.

Photo by/Author: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Jao Bautista
comments:
Went there.  Bought a beautiful man's waist bag from one dancer that had metal pieces which "tinkle" when shaken.  Lovely people. Sweet and giving.  Did some hiking in the rice terraces...met wonderful people there.$$huh igorot i mzz that costume$$its more fun in the philippines

eating rice grown and harvested from rice terraces

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Boracay, Aklan

What is it like? 
Before the last day of the year, Filipinos will be busy preparing for Media Noche ‚Äì the New Year's eve feast. There will be firecrackers, noisemakers and 12 kinds of round fruits on dinner tables, because these are believed to bring wealth in the coming year. 

Fun Fact: 
Don't be surprised if you see Filipinos jumping as high as they can at midnight on New Year's eve. There's a superstition that doing this will make you taller. While most people know it's just an old wives' tale, they still do the New Year jump for the fun of it. 

Photo by/Author: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Tin Sanchez

message+desc:
TaxiMonger brings Johor Bahru‚Äôs first taxi booking service through smartphones for trips to Malaysia. Passengers can book for metered taxis whether on adhoc basis or in advance. Exclusively partnered with JB-Tek Bhd to connect passengers in Singapore with the taxi-drivers of JB-Tek Bhd for a service app called as ‚ÄòTrip To Malaysia‚Äô.
Passengers from Singapore would now be able to go to any of the tourists‚Äô destinations, points of interests and key cities in Malaysia through JB-Tek‚Äôs assigned Executive Taxis. The selected destinations offered by TaxiMonger range from as near as Johor Bahru and going as far as Pulau Langkawi. 

For more information, log on to www.taximonger.com
comments: Hi Maryati. This is particular service of 'Trip To Malaysia' is from Singapore to anywhere in Malaysia. For Singapore to JB, it would be SGD50 for one-way trip per taxi.

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Obando, Bulacan 

What is it like? 
Want a baby? Every year, single men and women and childless couples dance in the streets to seek help from the patron saints of matchmaking and fertility: Sta. Clara, San Pascual de Baylon and the Virgin of Salambao. 

Fun Fact: 
Local fishermen and farmers join in the dancing as well but instead of praying for children, they ask for a good harvest! With all the dancing involved, it's almost impossible not to join in yourself, whatever your intentions may be!

Photo by/Author: 
Norma Belleza from the collection of Mr. & Mrs. Elmer Sarmiento /Wanggo Gallaga
comments: sayaw din tayo sec s obando..hehe:-)$$The Fertility Dance Festival is held in Obando, Bulacan every May 17, 18, & 19. First day is for San Pascual, 2nd for Sta. Clara, and the last day for the Our Lady of Salambao

Find out what they have to say about this.  

http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-34645078It is the most surreal and wildly popular show you may have never heard of, smashing social media records becoming an internet phenomenon. But what is Aldub?

message+desc:
Vaishali attracts visitors who come to this district town in Bihar for a close encounter with history and spirituality. One of the greatest cities of the 5th century BC, Vaishali is credited with being the world's first republic to have a duly elected assembly of representatives and efficient administration. The place finds mention in the great epic Ramayana. Buddha spent the last rainy season of life near the city of Vaishali and Lord Mahavir, the founder of Jainism, was born here. The second Buddhist Council was held in this town 100 years after Buddha‚Äôs death. 

- See more at: http://www.incredibleindia.org/travel/destination/vaishali
comments: Thank you MoT fot sharing such stories. .Really helpful ...

message+desc:
[Updated!] KTM Shuttle Guide: Singapore To JB On An Old-School Train In Just 5 Minutes 

PSA: To help you better utilize the SIN/RM exchange rate, Shuttle Tebrau has added 8 MORE TRIPS to its existing schedule. 3-hour jams that make our butts hurt are so 2015.

Here's what you can expect from the rail experience!  

http://thesmartlocal.com/read/ktm-shuttle-guideImagine a train that gets you from from Singapore to JB in 5 minutes flat, for only $5 a trip. Oh wait, that exists. Here's our guide to KTM's Shuttle Tebrau!
comments:
Ey. Just take the public transport buses? You save money AND time. 

No extra tickets required since you're continueing a journey and you already took public buses there. No need to go 30 minutes earlier and all that. Walking distance is roughly the same if you count walking to/fro/within the train station.

There's a reason why the people who travel in and out frequently, especially those who work here and stay there, hardly ever use the KTM shuttle.

Or. You could do a 'challenge. Have 2 of use either methods and see what happens.

Also, if you're using the train to go further (i.e. KL), get the tickets from JB side. A little more troublesome and can only board from JB (so that public transport there), but the tickets are the same amount, just in ringgit, so it's about 1/3 the price there now.$$@thesmartlocal.com why do your "test" trip on a weekday at 5pm? Do a real world "test" on a Saturday morning. Then report on what a breezy experience it would be.$$How to buy the ticket?on line or on the sport....$$Xjingg Lim can take on sat$$Raymond Chan, Yvonne Chan, Chan Vivien. Sound good. Can try.

message+desc:
A 90 min drive from Cairns will take you to one of Australia's best kept secrets - a Spanish Castle known today as Paronella Park.

Walk through century-old courts, tunnels and bridges and explore this castle home and its surroundings, including the 7,000+ trees planted 80 years ago. 

SilkAir flies directly to Cairns thrice a week. Australia's "Capital of Adventure" is just a $779 ticket away. (All-in 2-to-go fare)

More information at silkair.com/cairns.

message+desc:
Rameswaram - A holy site sanctified by the Ramayan

Rameswaram, the holy island in the Gulf of Mannar, is a major pilgrim centre of the country. 
Rameswaram is hallowed by the epic Ramayana. It is believed that Lord Rama sanctified this place by worshipping Lord Shiva here after the war against Ravana of Sri Lanka. 

Therefore, it is held sacred by both Vishnu and Shiva devotees. It is one of the 12 Jyothirlinga shrines (where Lord Shiva is worshipped as a ‚ÄòLingam (pillar) of light‚Äô) of India. A devout Hindu who visits Varanasi in the North must also visit Rameswaram for the culmination of his quest for salvation.

- See more at: http://www.incredibleindia.org/travel/destination/rameswaram
comments:
Check out The Telegraph 's map of countries with the most Unesco World Heritage sites - India high, with 32 http://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/travelnews/11769055/Mapped-Which-countries-have-the-most-World-Heritage-Sites.html$$Lovely n I wanna go there in my life........$$untouched beauty 
I stayed for 10 hours at rameshwar 7 yrs back  but still when  I recall it I feel like visiting  agn$$It's worth going I must try my best to go

message+desc:
We don't normally travel to the West. But we made an exception for Singapore's ONLY abandoned railway station!

Formerly a busy railway station, the Bukit Timah Rail Corridor now serves as a sentimental reminder of Singapore's past. Built in 1903, the authorities have announced that they will seal off the area around the old Bukit Timah Station in the first quarter of this year so we decided to return to take one last look at it before it's too late!

Read our guide here:
http://www.thesmartlocal.com/read/bukit-timah-rail-corridor-guide

Address: 1 Bukit Timah Railway Station, Singapore 599938

Never want to miss a post by us again?
Like TheSmartLocal.com and set Notifications to "All On"

Director: Ria Chia Cai Yun I Models: Samantha Ngain and Ria
comments: Uh, TheSmartLocal.com, this railway line was not built in 1903, but in 1932. The original line was built in 1903 and ran along Dunearn Road from Woodlands to Tank Road. There were stations at Newton, cluny, and Stevens road, but it was demolished in 1930 and replaced with the current KTM Line :)$$Elizabeth Sham this looks like a good weekend adventure!$$C√©zanne Yeo We until now still havent go!~$$Can we still visit the railway?$$YongWen Tan we haven't go here loh$$Shall we ? Hilmi Hans Hamzah

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Boracay, Aklan

What is it like? 
Ah, Boracay. Need we say more? Since much has been said, raved and written about this famous four-kilometer stretch of powder white sand paradise, we would like to suggest you try the most exhilarating activity off it ‚Äî cliff-diving at Ariel's Point. The highest plank is about 15 meters high, which is as high as a five-storey building. But a jump off it ends with a safe, pleasantly wet landing.

Fun Fact: 
Not a lot of people know that Tribal Adventure Day Tours are offered on this island. These are no ordinary tours. You spend an entire day getting to know the indigenous people living In the area. The women will welcome you into their homes and even cook for your group while you learn about their history and customs. Ask around for D'Arcy Kelly. He runs the show.

Photo by/Author: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Donna Dimayuga
comments: Indeed BORACAY is one of the best beaches in the PI and very well known and visited by many BAK]$$Voted by international tourism magazine as one of the best destination for holidays and venue of 2015 APEC summit conference$$"BORACAY" is one of the best beaches here in the "PHILIPPINES"$$Boracay is TripAdvisor's 2014 best beach in Asia :)$$I want go in the boracay someday.. .$$I will be there next month.$$i will come to borocay to play football only goes on the top of the list for my winter holiday to-do list hahaha$$Been there....amazing!  Can highly recommend for your trip plans!$$don't missed the island cove!$$Honeymooned there in 1992. A place like no other!! $$I been there . Just like a very beautiful paradise love the boracay :)

message+desc:
Ï∂îÏÑù(Chuseok; Korean Thanksgiving) is by far the biggest and most important holiday in Korea. It is a time when family members from near and far come together to share food and stories, and to give thanks to their ancestors for the abundant harvest. This year, Chuseok Day falls on September 30th.

Find out more about Ï∂îÏÑù: http://bit.ly/SkPsnu
comments: thank you for sharing ...how interesting ... i love the extended family idea ...$$wow .. great time to the family.. like Lebaran in Indonesia$$wow love this festival so colorful and yet traditional$$CHINESE MID AUTUMN MOONCAKE FESTIVAL on 30/9 this year!$$Chuseok is a great family celebration - we were in Korea during Chuseok in 2010.$$i can say freely that chouseak is the best season in south korea it is a time where all the members of the familly share the same feeling of great happiness while they celebrate the chouseak i would like if i can go to south korea to celebrate it with you$$Chuseok is really an important occassion especially for families because it is the time for bonding like playing games and eating together.$$i really want to feel chuseok..like i always with my family on mooncake festival..but pity me due to study i can't celebrate with my family this year..$$I have uploaded a post on chuseok in my blog "mystic korea"$$the great Chuseok is coming!!$$A nice new information about Korea~$$Have a bountiful Chuseok..:)

message+desc:
Wouldn‚Äôt you like to free yourself from the stress in your life?
A journey to the UNESCO World Heritage Site, ‚ÄúYakushima Island‚Äù, could be the answer.
Located in southern Japan in Kagoshima Prefecture, this island with ancient, immense forest filled with magnificent trees estimated to be over 2,000 years old is waiting for you.
Looking for activities? The main highlight is a hike through lush vegetation that takes between one to ten hours to complete, depending on the course. You may even catch a glimpse of wild monkeys or deer on the road!

Related Information
http://japan-magazine.jnto.go.jp/en/1503_yakushima.html 
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/rtg/pdf/pg-708.pdf
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/indepth/scenic/worldheritage/c_12_yakushima.html
comments: I am lucky enough to have been. It is worth the trip for the forests alone, it is an incredible place. Beyond that though there are a few onsen as well, including one in a rock pool down on the shore, beaches and waterfalls. You can see monkeys as you can see above and there are deer as well. The people I interacted with were also really friendly and helpful.$$Why do you torture me with all these beautiful places I want to see but cant right now?!$$I have been to monkey island so enjoyed it dident realise you come face to face with the monkeys$$Japan is a CHEATER on volleyball today... Go to hell JAPAN..... JAPAN has no SPIRIT....

message+desc:
Climbing up the Ifugao Rice Terraces is definitely an adventure as this guy from The Huffington Post tells us in this article! Read on and find out why this destination is often called the "Eighth Wonder of the World."

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/clint-johnston/a-journey-to-the-rice-ter_b_3673114.htmlThe terraces of Batad are a stunning scene to behold, sculpted like giant staircases from the mountains of Ifugao. Considered a backpackers Mecca by many, the rice terraces are a worthwhile journey. My journey to Batad began atop a jeepney, which was a unique experience in itself.

O:);););):D:D$$Truly a sight to behold ! I consider myself lucky to have grown up in a province ( Nueva Vizcaya) that  is only 2 hours away from these stairways to the sky.$$Ive been to Batad Rice Terraces and Tappiya Waterfalls. Magnificent wonders of nature!$$Was there 1 year ago ...marvellous ....$$Too bad it takes a foreigner to see the beauty of the country  and the irony of it all many pilipinos prefered to visit other countries$$I've been there...its totally amazing place..$$This place is truly amazing.

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Siargao, Surigao del Norte

What is it like? 
The Philippines isn‚Äôt a major surf destination yet. That means more waves for you. We recommend hitting the beaches of Siargao, the country's surfing capital. Its popular surfing points have interesting names: Jack Horse, Quiksilver and the famous Cloud 9 ‚Äî known for its thick, perfect hollow tubes. It‚Äôs only been a few decades since American surf enthusiasts brought their boards to the Philippines, but our beaches have really taken to surf culture. As they should. They‚Äôve got water and waves to spare.

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila to Surigao (one hour), then take a boat to Siargao.

Or take a bus from Manila or Davao to Surigao, then take a boat to Siargao.

Or take a boat from Manila to Surigao, then take a boat to Siargao.

Fun Fact: 
International surfers call Cloud 9's perfect tubes as "the special wave." The wave was discovered by traveling surfers in the late 1980s. It was named and made famous by American photographer John S. Callahan.

Photo by/Author: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Donna Dimayuga
comments: I need to go back there it's beautiful..when is the best surf season Habagat or Amihan ?$$I've been in siargao cloud 9 way back 1999..but I'll be visiting my beloved country Philippines this year..see you soon!God willing..$$I guess l gotta check this place out. The last time I was there my driver would only take me to San Juan on the south china  sea side of the Philippines$$I want to get there so very badly

message+desc:
ZAZEN, or Zen Meditation is a form of mental or spiritual method of training. 
There are two major Zen sects, RINZAI and SOTO. Generally, meditators sit in lotus position against a wall in the RINZAI sect, and in the SOTO sect, meditators sit in facing a wall. 
If you would like to study more, please refer to the following link;
SOTO http://global.sotozen-net.or.jp/eng/practice/zazen/howto/
RINZAI http://www.rinzaizen.org/

Related information;
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/indepth/cultural/experience/w.html
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/indepth/cultural/kie/zen/
http://japan-magazine.jnto.go.jp/en/1308_zen.html
comments: I tried once in a monastery in Kyoto. Great culture experience.$$Grace Lin I just had a flashback to Komazawa days! Going to Japan Jan and April... Very excited xx$$Than a japanese to a foreigner a fan many, good one this how?$$Yes, the good old memories!

[Updated] 23 Words Mispronounced By Singaporeans Their Whole Lives

Get your pronunciation right this new year with our UPDATED list.

Is flour pronounced "flahr" or "flower"? Here are 23 words Singaporeans have been mispronouncing all their lives. 99.9% of Singaporeans mispronounce #9.

Follow TheSmartLocal.com and never miss our best posts again!

http://www.thesmartlocal.com/read/words-singaporeans-mispronounceIs flour pronounced "flahr" or "flower"? Here are 23 words Singaporeans have been mispronouncing all their lives. 99.9% of Singaporeans mispronounce #9.
comments: Put it this way, when US started mispronouncing and misspelling all the English words, they didn't go doubting and criticising their own English. Instead they were proud to do things their own way, and now US English is on equal footing as UK English. But Singapore is different and is forever looking for some existing rule and standard to follow so she can feel safer that she is doing the right thing

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Dahican Beach, Davao Oriental

What is it like? 
Boracay's four-kilometer stretch not enough for you? Behold this stunning seven-kilometer stretch of white sand, with towering coconut trees as lush accents. Dahican Beach is widely popular beach destination for skimboarding. It's also a place for observing marine life, as dolphins, sea cows and sea turtles inhabit its waters.

Fun Fact: 
Kuya Jun Plaza is a native Dahican and founder of the Amihan Boys ‚Äì a group of the best skimboarders and surfers in the region. He doesn't only teach them how to get better at their sport, but also gives life lessons on how to stay away from vices and use their passions to help others. Try to meet him and shake his hand when you're in the area.

Photo by/Author: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Donna Dimayuga

Pinoys and tourists should visit Dahican in Mati City...$$I can't wait to come there someday and check out those white sandy beaches I want to visit the Philippines and meet a lot of the people$$Haw far,, bus ride from Davao to mati ? I'll be there on my vacation. This will probably included in my itinerary. Love it.$$Yeah in amihan dahican beach skim boarders and surfers will love this place coz of its huge waves, must visit this place$$i plan to try dahican soon... looks arsome!$$near,in MY place, ,,amazing. message+desc:
Jog Falls - Feast from Nature
------------------------------------------------------------------------

Witness nature‚Äôs headlong tumble, as the Sharavati River makes a spectacular drop of 956 ft in four distinct cascades ‚Äì known locally as Raja, Rani, Roarer and Rocket ‚Äì to create the fifth highest falls in Asia. One of India‚Äôs greatest scenic wonders, the Jog Falls is at their exuberant best during the monsoon, with arching rainbows colouring the mist. 

When the sluice gates of the upstream Linganamakki Dam are closed, taking a walk right down to the bottom of the gorge is a once-in-a-lifetime experience. A large hydro electric power plant is located down stream here. 

- See more at: http://incredibleindia.org/index.php/travel/destination/jog-falls

message+desc:
Take it from this Swede who has lived in both countries.Some may wish they could leave Singapore and live in a place like, say, Sweden.

But is Sweden really better than Singapore? This Swedish guy made 2 videos to say: NO.

https://mustsharenews.com/singapore-sweden-videos/
comments:
I think Singaporeans take housing for granted the most. Across the world, house ownership is a pipe dream for an entire generation of millennials. Not to say housing in SG is perfect, but at least it's attainable.$$Having to visit Stockholm a month ago, I tend to agree that SG is better than Sweden (while I do like their architecture). Their cabs are insane, no regulations and touting for business and ridiculously priced. The licensed one that I took cost me S$80 from airport to city and the drive said unlicensed ones can cost up to S$200... Unlike other Scandinavian countries, people there don't seem to be as friendly or happier... Food and transport were also more expensive than Denmark and Finland, even public areas are dirtier than their 2 counterparts. So yeah, I'll pick SG anytime over Sweden$$Why bother to compare and say which is better? There will always be things that are better on 1 side but there will also be things that are worse. It's like when you are in school and got 89 marks for your test. And then your mom comes and say why u no like the other kid who got 92 marks and ignoring the fact that your 89 mark is actually the second highest, better than the other 30 kids in the class. Sigh....$$Be contented with what you have. Singaporeans complain too much. If singapore was so bad then please give up your space to someone who will appreciate it more.$$The grass is always greener on the other side, there's no perfect system of governance, just a better balance of left and right...$$Singapore is great if you can afford to uber everywhere like the  Swedish guy,  or afford private housing which that guy seems to ('much more attractive option anyway' or something like that)$$Sure you wanna compare?
... Singapore government taxes us More than 300 over percent for buying just a car, and that's exclude the earnings our local car dealers are profiting in the process$$Malaysia even much better than both countries provided you are not align to any politics here . Expatriates with their salaries have a wonderful life here.$$I think he forgot to compare salary vs living cost to yield expendable income, it is not fair to compare just area vs area without comparing the above. For vandalism and subway, I agree that SG is way better than any other country (except HK :P) due to absolute strict law. No cigarette butt due to strict law again. Glass door on subway station and the safety cone on construction area / road is for safety and to avoid subway company and government bodies being sued by passenger accident. While due to strict law, order is there always. This area Singapore always better than any other country in the world.$$Rubbish article. In SG, most of the time you do not own the property but rent it for 99 years.  And that is full rental payment up front upon signing the "ownership" lease.

Transport is easy becos we are a small city.  MRT?  Rofl!  Really?  Dun think all our MRTs have screen doors.  All of them started WITHOUT screen doors and we had our share of people being pushed or fell onto the tracks.

He should really do more research before posting this fake news.$$Might as well compare our houses to mansion houses and say we are deplorables? 

This goalpost changing where everyone has their own criteria is annoying.

Everyone wants the MRT to be better. Like common$$I have also lived in both countries and this article is so biased it is not even funny$$Cos they are treated special here with the Asians kowtowing to them??..Back, in Sweden, they are just common White..üòÇ$$Try stealing a chair in singapore lor... you can go jail and get fine... lol singapore so small where you gonna run ? And why would Singaporean wanna steal a chair that's worth $50-$100 when the fine is $2000 and get jailed... probably because Singaporean will think of consequences first before acting.$$He just tasting the icying on the cake.. wait till he gets the whole cake and see if Singapore is still sweet...$$Singaporeans take things for granted. Only if they have lived abroad for a few years will they then know its Great To Be Home (SINGAPORE). i HOPE THIS VIDEO BY STEFAN WAKES SINGAPOREANS UP ESPECIALLY THE YOUNG ONES.$$Housing and transport. SG is only better if you have 3 to 4 times more cash than the middle class folks in these countries. And sg weather is hot and humid uncomfortable!$$The girls in Sweden are hotter. Nothing to do with this article but a valid point for choosing Sweden.$$Because you are not Singapore citizen, yet.$$Most singaporean ÁîüÂú®Á¶è‰∏≠Ôºå‰∏çÁü•Á¶èÔºÅJust know how to complain and expect things to be in their 'perfect' way!$$That's show how FTs are not welcome to theirs country....so stop dreaming.$$I just read the comments and again I'm reminded that people only hear/see what they want. Sigh...$$The cool climate are already 5 points up above SG as what I think$$Sometimes... people need to be kicked out of their own country to know how good it is... with or without it.$$Litmus test. Ask him if he wants to be a Singaporean citizen.

Beam me there Scottie!$$Yes, a kind of snail, mixed in with slices off fresh cucumbers, carrots, onions, pear, in a slightly spicy gochujang hot pepper sauce. $$Thanks for the details.. Sure sounds delicious. Must try! Thanks for sharing.$$Snail. Never had those. Interesting.$$
I am Canadian, and always thought the idea of eating snail was sort of funny.  But when I came to Korea, I made a resolution to try every food at least once.  And prepared the way it is displayed above, it is really yummy. Snail has a similar texture to steamed shellfish but just a different shape. If you get a chance to try it, please do! :)

Marie$$Hi, Marie. I do hope I get to go to Korea next year so, I can try it out myself. =)

message+desc:
Have you ever heard about  the mermaids of Jeju island? 
They are known as haenyeo Ìï¥ÎÖÄ, or Korean female divers. Unlike fishermen who go out in boats or use a rod or line, these women dive in the ocean without any special tools to gather clams, abalone, or seaweed! :o *Respects* 

You can learn more about them at the Jeju Haenyeo Museum!
Click here for more info ‚òû http://bit.ly/1L0M0fK

#Ìï¥ÎÖÄ #WomenDivers #Jeju #VisitKorea

message+desc:
Did you know that there are two types transportation cards that you can get for traveling around in Korea? T-money can be used on public buses and subways in several different metropolitan cities besides Seoul while M-Pass is a transportation card that offers 20 rides a day for the duration of the pass in the Seoul Metropolitan City area and Jeju! Plus, they are both refundable! Which one do YOU prefer? :D

Click here to find out more! ‚òû http://bit.ly/12CsTqU

#SeoulMetropolitanArea #Subway #TMoney #MPass #VisitKorea
comments:
I alway use T-money, because I can also use it at the convenience store to purchase something. Also to pay for taxi in Seoul.$$I was only able to use t-money and I like it because I can use it to pay in buses, cabs and convenience stores. And they said it does not expire so I can still use mine when I go back right?$$I don't prefer one. I like to have them both. It's great to know this. I wouldnt be clueless if ever I have to these cards someday. hehe #stillwishing$$I have a Cashbee card, can it be used the same way as T-money? (:$$Daegu discriminates against people who want to charge their t money card. Byeongchul Kim$$T-money coz I can use it also in metropolitan cities. Plus it has no expiration, I can recharge it when I go back to Korea. Plus for those Hallyu/KPOP fans, there are personalized T-money of ur fave stars. Got mine here of my fave kpop group SS501. :)$$T-Money!! They come in different styles and cute designs too! :D$$Hehe...this is what I use when in Korea...T-Money$$They both are superb and efficient but if I had to choose then I would choose T-Money. 
We don't have anything this easy and convenient for our public transport here in Cape Town, South Africa. I miss Korea :($$Used T-Money when we visited last year. I still have it with me! üòÜ$$i have the tosca one hehe$$T-money should be ok..!!$$I used T-money...I travelled everywhere...$$I like that they are refundable. T-money sounds super convenient!$$T money. Because I felt it is cheaper than the m pass. :)
