message+desc: "Ask a Korean" is a blog site where you call email your questions to "The Korean" (what the blogger calls himself). Who knows, he may even answer your question on his site! By the way, what do YOU think about pizza on the traditional Jesa table?^^;; Leave a comment and let's talk more this weekend!Well, as long as the ancestor in question liked pizza, I think it wouldn't be too bad. And people are already ordering Jesa foods anyway...
comments: I used to read AAKs Blog hoping to understand Korean culture better now that I am living here, but was disappointed at how often he  unfavorably talks about US of A. I believe that we should respect our differences and appreciate that they don't need to be labeled "right" or "wrong."$$Really? That's so sad to hear.„Ö†„Ö† I just saw the site today and thought it was an interesting concept. Wonder if I should remove it?$$I know! There were some really great blog posts and I followed the blog and facebook, too. But as the year passed I realized that I was upset by more posts than I enjoyed. Still, maybe I'm overly sensitive? Check out a few of his posts... he posts on a variety of subjects.$$I think the issue of sometimes critical opinions regarding america is something any expat of their country is bound to do with the country they've moved to. You notice a number of things- changes in courtesies, changes in formalities, food, discrimination, the list goes on. We went through this a lot in japan as exchange students- we had people that didn't want to sit next to us on occasion on the train, no one holds open doors in Japan (not out of an effort to be rude, but just because it's not part of their common courtesy), american versions of food outside of mcdonalds and hard rock were usually hilariously wrong, etc. We became very critical of Japan, not because we didn't like it there (we LOVED it there- many of my friends are already back), but because in talking through the harsh realities, it helped us cope and adjust to the differences. Many of our Japanese friends were slightly shocked at our perspectives on occasion, but they couldn't deny that there wasn't any truth to it. The Korea seems to do the same sort of thing, except this time the foreign country is america and america is full of changes he has to be critical of to understand and cope and adapt to. Perhaps I'm more understanding because I know where he's coming from, but instead of seeing it as a personal attack (which is far from what he probably intends), see it as an alternate perspective of someone who hasn't been ingrained in american culture since birth and therefore has a fresh perspective on perhaps some of the more harsher realities of living here. :)$$@Mary: Very insightful! I've seen both sides of it...people for the USA being very critical of Korea and many Koreans being critical of the USA. I think you may have hit the nail on the head...more than anything it may be a way to fit a new culture into their mindset more than an actual attack. However...there definitely is a limit too. I guess a lot depends on not just WHAT is said, but HOW it is said!$$^I agree! There are of course things you shouldn't say, but I've not seen anything written in this blog that seemed to absolutely cross the line with this sort of cultural reaction. I HAVE seen people cross it, and it's pretty obvious when they do. And generally most critiques about a country are kept amongst those who are collectively together in the new environment, not shouted from the rooftops, haha. The only time I had japanese friends of mine hear me speak about my own critiques is when I had to speak to a group of out-going american exchange students about what not to do and what to expect when going to Japan. Otherwise I don't generally talk about that sort of thing, haha. But since 'The Korean' has made an open blog about it, I can see how that might step on some toes of people who can't yet share the same perspective, but at the same time it's a good resource for learning relevant information from a down-to-earth point of view I think. :)

message+desc:
Good news for those who are coming to Japan in winter and who want to see sakura (cherry blossoms) during your visit!
Take a look at a picture of beautiful sakura and it's actually taken in winter!

Sakura generally blooms in April in Japan, but this one called "Atami Sakura" which can be seen at  Atami City (Shizuoka Pref.) has its peak in Jan. to Feb. because of the mild climate. 

It's only 45 mins away from Tokyo by bullet train and now Sakura Festival is being held until 12th Feb.! So why don't you drop in at this city? You can enjoy spas and Mt.Fuji as well!

For more information (PDF) : http://www.city.atami.shizuoka.jp/www/contents/1235030728490/files/atami_inbound.pdf

message+desc:
[Club Med Giveaway!] 25 Amazing Things To Do In Bintan Other Than Lepaking At Resorts 

Most people think beaches are all there is to Bintan. Most people are wrong. Over a week, our team rode toured through a mangrove, flew on jetpacks and uncovered 500 statues hidden in a Chinese temple. 

We're giving away a 3D2N stay at Club Med Bintan (worth $1968)! All you have to do is:

1. Like Bintan Resorts and TheSmartLocal.com
2. Share this post and tell us why you should win in the comments below! 

Contest ends 24 May and the winner will be notified on 25 May. 

http://thesmartlocal.com/read/visit-bintanIf you thought Bintan was just beach resorts and school camps, you thought wrong. An undiscovered paradise awaits you, just a 60 minute ferry ride away!

message+desc:
Where is it?
Banaue Rice Terraces, Ifugao

How To Get There:
Take a bus bound for Banaue from Sampaloc. 

Or take a bus bound for Baguio from Cubao or Pasay, then transfer to a bus bound for Banaue.

What Is It?
These 2,000 year old rice terraces were carved into the mountains of Ifugao by ancestors of the indigenous people.

Fun Fact:
This UNESCO World Heritage Site is still in use today.

Photo by  / Headline by:
Daniel Carpentier  / Cecile Golez

Banaue is a town and batad is a village. From banaue, u have to ride a jeep to saddle and walk about 4hrs to get in batad. Good thing the roads were now cemented unlike before, no jeep can go to saddle so u have to walk/hike for 6 hrs or more. Haha! Good luck to those who will visit our place. Enjoy :)$$it is more convenient travelling to banaue from manila, what happened to suspension of gv florida bus...$$Great location and beautiful scenery. message+desc:
Where is it? 
El Nido, Palawan

What is it like? 
Starfish, also known as sea stars, are one of the most popular creatures on the sea bed. Although Palawan has a place called Starfish Island in Honda Bay, this particular orange starfish was found biding its time on Snake Island.

Fun Fact: 
The mouth of a starfish is found in its center. Though it's hard to imagine, these creatures have intestines and a stomach. But they also have an ability to digest food outside their bodies, and so can feed on prey much larger than their mouths.

Photo by/Author: 
Tin Sanchez
comments: At the northern part of palawan.. from puerto princesa city to roxas 135km. Next roxas to taytay 75km. Taytay to el nido35km.. enjoy ur journey....

message+desc:
The Chuncheon International Mime festival features exciting innovative mime and street performances that showcases the talents of many master performers. Chuncheon is within easy reach of Seoul. Trains and buses depart frequently for Chuncheon, and it is about a two-hour drive. As well as the festival, there are several popular tourist destinations located nearby Chuncheon, including Namiseom Island and the Soyangang Dam. 

The festival offers at least 80 performances from mime troupes from Korea as well as famous international troupes from Taiwan, Denmark, Germany, and other countries. This non-verbal mime festival is a unique opportunity for non-Korean speakers to enjoy Korea‚Äôs modern performing arts. 

More info: http://bit.ly/KvFf7SThe Chuncheon International Mime festival features exciting innovative mime and street performances that showcases the talents of many master performers. Chuncheon is within easy reach of Seoul. Trains and buses depart frequently for Chuncheon, and it is about a two-hour drive. As well as the festival, there are several popular tourist destinations located nearby Chuncheon, including Namiseom Island and the Soyangang Dam. 

The festival offers at least 80 performances from mime troupes from Korea as well as famous international troupes from Taiwan, Denmark, Germany, and other countries. This non-verbal mime festival is a unique opportunity for non-Korean speakers to enjoy Korea‚Äôs modern performing arts. 

More info: http://bit.ly/KvFf7S

message+desc:
The Samgwangsa Temple Lantern Festival in Busan is a definite must-see if you are coming to Korea in May! To celebrate the Buddha‚Äôs birthday, thousands of brightly colored lanterns are strung up all across the temple. The lighting of the festival will begin this Sunday, May 3 while the actual Buddha's birthday falls on May 25 :)

How to get there?
Get off at Seomyeon Station (Busan Line 1) and Exit 13.
Take Bus No. 54, 63, 81,133 from the bus stop in front of the entrance of Bucheon Market. Get off at the entrance of Samgwangsa Temple bus stop.

#ÏÇºÍ¥ëÏÇ¨ #Î∂ÄÏÇ∞ #Ïó∞Îì±Ï∂ïÏ†ú #MustSee #Samgwangsa #VisitKorea

What's your tribe? The Triboa Bay Mangrove Park in Subic, Zambales is an ecotone -- a critical area where two ecosystems meet. message+desc:
Where is it? 
Calanggaman Island, Leyte

What is it like? 
By those who know about it, this ten-hectare hidden gem is adored for its supremely fine white sands. But the real adventure begins below the surface ‚Äì with up to 30-meter visibility and an expansive reef, this marine reserve also provides a mystifying dive experience.

How to get there: 
Fly from Manila to Calbayog or Tacloban. Or take a bus from Manila to Tacloban. Or take a boat from Cebu to Calbayog or Ormoc.

Fun Fact: 
The island gets its name from the Cebuano word for bird, possibly owing to the two sandbars that stretch out like wings from its shores.

Photo by/Author: 
Jeffrey Bautista/Magnus Ahmad
comments: It is found here in "Palompon leyte"very nice beach.$$Wondering what to do in Leyte? message+desc:
#UNESCOdesignated: Changdeokgung Palace Ï∞ΩÎçïÍ∂Å
Listed as a #UNESCO World Cultural Heritage site in 1997, #Changdeokgung is the most well-preserved of the five remaining royal #places. It is comprised of a public palace area, a #royal family residence, and a rear #garden, also now commonly known as the 'secret garden'. Don't forget to check out the gigantic tree that is over 300 years old, the #beautiful small reflecting pond and the pavilion when you visit! :D 

Find out more ‚òû bit.ly/UNESCOchangdeokgung
comments: I have just returned from Seoul, where I spent 3 great days taking pictures of this beautiful city! I made photo reports from Changdeokgung, Bongeunsa temple and Dongdaemun Design Plaza, but Changdeokgung is the best one because of it's Secret Garden. Truly beautiful place!$$Glad to have visited this palace on my first trip to korea...i really love the secret garden and the long walks to experience the beauty of the whole place <3$$I think Korea is one of the most beautiful countries over the world.$$Been here and i just love the place$$I will definitely visit Changdokgung Palace during mg trip this coming March. I am very excited! üòÅ$$I was there last summer & "The Rooftop Prince" came to mind$$There is beautiful place!$$i wanted to visit Changdeokgung Palace Ï∞ΩÎçïÍ∂Å' meet that 300 years old tree, see the secret garden and that reflecting pond and pavilion>,<$$Wonderful place... recommend to catch the secret garden tour when you are visiting... worth a visit

message+desc: Are you interested to explore the beauty of Indonesia? If so, there‚Äôs good news for you! The Indonesian government has given a free visa for 90 countries. #WonderfulIndonesia
comments:
as Indonesian, i am ashame that the guy who made this picture didn't know that Czechoslovakia has disappeared since 1992 and the government of Indonesia gives an extended visa free to a defunct non-existent country. Come on Indonesia...$$I hope its vice versa for indonesian passport holder to visit those countries tho :D$$So the truth about the visa free entry,is that like most things jokowi has tried to do, the corrupt embedded systems have found away around it.  

The way corrupt immigration officials have managed to get around this one are:
1)reducing the 90 free visa (as it is in most of asean)  to 30 days then with a intrusive,  unfriendly,  nasty and corrupt extension possible at immigration offices. 
2)not providing it to the largest incoming tourist group in Bali, Australians,  because a) corrupt officials at the airport are so dependant on that cash coming in.  These are the same government officials who always guarantee there are not enough immigration officers working at anyone time at the Bali airport so that they can offer a discrete express service foe an extra  cash fee and b) just to childishly spite Australia, claiming it is because Australia does not reciprocate with free visa for Indonesians,  conveniently over looking that many many of the 90 countries on the list also don't offer free visas to Indonesians. 
3)only making it available at a few very specific ports of entry,  Jakarta,  Batam, Bali and maybe one or two others,  but yogya for example misses out, which is why some have written that they still had to pay. 
4)by going back to being much more strict on demanding that you already have a return ticket booked out of the country,  which is of course ridiculous in this modern age of last minute online cheap tickets from budget carriers like Air Asia. 

So yeah! Yep we have restricted and still unfriendly in welcoming very short visas foe some countries at some airports.  There is no doubt that is better than before,  but sadly like. Most things Jokowi has tried to do,  it has been watered down dramatically by the old guard, including Mega and JK,  Golkar and the rest of the embedded corrupt government cronies. 
Sad but true
And who loses 
As always outer Indonesia as noone stays long enough to get out there.$$Any valid information about this 90 daya free visa to Indonesia?$$I will visit Indonesia this Christmas. So no more on arrival visa?$$Indonesia is not an English speaking country anyways. Mistakes on the writing above are still forgivable. And it's understandable.$$Do you Interest = *Are you interested*

Earlier given Visa Free = *Visa exempted countries*

Is okay, mistakes do happens sometimes. Let's learn to forgive. :) Peace!$$the country providing the most turis turis to Indonesia is .... AUSTRALIA$$OK, So when will WNI can get at least VOA and don't need to make visa in advance for japan, South Korea, European country, USA, south & north America, and more???$$Shall we go Virzah?
But we're Indonesian anyway$$So why I had to pay $35 2 weeks ago?$$Really that's mean Jordanian now have free visa, ,,$$Narelle Williams this is great news. Means no fees right !?

message+desc:
Our history tells us that we had "50 years in Hollywood"! And there's no better city to show the American influence than Baguio. Here are 10 places in the City of Pines that show us why Baguio is "Little America." 

http://www.rappler.com/life-and-style/travel/ph-travel/56434-places-baguio-little-americaCamp John Hay, Session Road, Baguio Cathedral are just a few of the spots that are rich with history in scenic Baguio City
comments:
such a nice place, people are kind and honest$$Manila should have been "the Paris of ASIA" , if only WW2 never destroyed  most of the infrastructures in our country's capital.$$It used to be a clean well-maintained city but now, it became rotten. Once the Americans left, the city officials neglected their duty to maintain cleanliness. Now it looks like an Ukay-Ukay City.$$Just got back from Baguio and it still has the power to relax your mind by looking at the lush greens$$proud to be from the little America! :-)$$I could no longer smell the fresh pine tree scent instead i smell the stinking odor along Session Road & wet market.$$i dont think u read the whole article mr.bryan.it was never mentioned that baguio resembles any part of america.and the pollution rank was a mistake.u need update.$$I have to agree with Brian Brian Mason. Been to Baguio twice only. Hated both times except for a period I was on a very private property that was well maintained.  
City traffic flows are horrible.  No road signs or means of direction. Dirty and polluted hillsides and streets.  
The mayor there wants to get rid of all American influence and he is doing a great job! This place now looks, smells and resembles every other dirty city in the Philippines.$$Proud to be from Baguio! #igorotak$$....what about the 300 years in the convent?$$Be proud to our country esp. the beautiful places like Baguio and many other places famous for their nice attractive views!! Nature from our Almighty God !!! Amen$$I went to Baguio the first time i visited Phillipines and i love it!

message+desc:
The far west is more than just home to factories and The Second Link - it's home to these 4 hidden gems too!

We kicked off our journey to the west with a visit to Thow Kwang Pottery Jungle - one of the last two Dragon Kilns in Singapore! Next up, we paid a visit to Singapore's first man-made swamp forest followed by a hike up Jurong Hill Park for a breathtaking view of Jurong Island. Finally, end off your adventure in the west by watching the sun set at the lighthouse at Raffles Marina!

Follow TheSmartLocal.com for more Singapore guides like this!

message+desc:
Who‚Äôs from Calamba, Laguna? Raise your hand! There‚Äôs a directional sign of your hometown in the town of Wilhemsfeld, Germany. The sign was erected in honor of our national hero, Jose Rizal, who hails from Calamba ‚Äì and who stayed a few months in Wilhemsfeld. Danke schoen! 

http://www.wheninmanila.com/look-to-pay-tribute-to-rizal-germany-has-a-city-of-calamba-sign/In 1886, Jose Rizal celebrated his 25th birthday in Wilhelmsfeld, Germany. In this quaint town, he celebrated his special day with a Lutheran minister, Karl Ulmer, and his family. Unknown to many, the Germans have deep attachment with Rizal. Apparently, our national hero is still remembered there. I...
comments:
sa Heidelberg, Germany may statue si Rizal at street..Jose Rizal strasse. at may sign board sa isang house where he stayed as a student of Opthometry in Heidelberg University.$$I'm from Calamba laguna nice place. Much More Fun in Cebu Philippines ...We are DELIGHTED to SERVE you with a ..SMILE$$This is  made possible because Calamba and Wilhelmsfeld (Baden-Wuerttemberg) are sister-cities since 2008. Rizal while Wilhelmsfeld is the small town where Rizal stayed with Pastor Ullmer to obtain a better appreciation of Germany (its culture and people).  As a tribute to Rizal, Wilhelmsfeld provides the venue for the only Rizal Park in Germany where annual pilgrimage by Knights of Rizal and Ladies for Rizal chapters from all over Europe congregate to commemorate Rizal's birth as well as death anniversaries (in June and December, respectively).$$The Germans have long loved the Philippines.$$WOW! thank you Wilhemsfeld, Germany..$$I'm from city of calamba. message+desc:
Where is it?
Callao Cave, Cagayan

How to Get There:
"Fly into Tuguegarao from Manila.

Take a bus bound for Tuguegarao or Aparri from Manila.

Or take a bus bound for Claveria from Ilocos Norte."

What is it?
Serious cavers will appreciate the different rock formations of Callao Cave. Casual tourists will appreciate that it doesn't take an expert to explore the area. Natural light highlights certain parts of the cave system, giving the rock formations even more texture. Be sure to bring your camera!

Fun Fact:
Callao Cave is a popular shoot location for Filipino movies and television shows. 

Photo by / Headline by:
Karlo Reyes Balisi/ Nikki Golez
comments: Have gorgeous pictures from there way before digital cameras or cell phones

message+desc:
If you are in Osaka, "Umeda Sky Building" is one of must-see landmarks.
The building is 173 meters high and has the Floating Garden Observatory where you can enjoy panoramic views of Osaka. 
They open at 5:00am on New Year's Day, so you might see the first sunrise of the year from the observatory!
 PHOTO COURTESY: Osaka Government Tourism Bureau
Area Information: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/osaka/umeda.html
Official Website: http://www.kuchu-teien.com/english/index.html

message+desc:
Eat Japanese cold noodle and stay cool!

"Somen" is firm crisp noodle, made by twisting them like a rope and straightening them, it is usually served cold in iced-water with a light flavored dipping sauce.
Main famous somen producing area is Hyogo Pref. Nara Pref. etc. 
There are many somen restaurants and tourists can enjoy flowing noodles.
 
Hyogo Pref.

On the second day of every New Year, some Japanese people do ‚ÄúKakizome‚Äù, which translates literally as ‚Äúthe first writing‚Äù. 
This traditional Japanese calligraphy event will be held at Tenmangu shrines in various regions such as the Kitano Tenmangu in Kyoto, the Hofu Tenmangu in Yamaguchi, the Dazaifu Tenmangu in Fukuoka, and more.
Would you like to give it a try as well?

In behalf of my friend Tshering Dorji a tour guide having an experience for 15 years and owner of Actual Bhutan Travel Agency are welcoming you all, to help processing your documents like visa for travelling to Bhutan. Actual Travel Bhutan

message+desc: The Hindu population in Bali celebrate their New Year in silence during Nyepi Day, which will fall on 28th March this year. On the eve of Nyepi, loud festivities will be held where papier-mach√© effigies or Ogoh-Ogoh are paraded around the village and along beaches to be burnt to cinders, denoting that all evil on this island has, thereby, been cleansed. On the day of Nyepi, however, the whole island will be trascend into serene silence when everyone meditates. #WonderfulIndonesiaEvery culture and religion in the world has its own way to define and celebrate the coming of the New Year. While the Chinese have the Lunar New Year celebrations, the Muslims celebrate the first of Muharram, and the world in general celebrates the first day of January, the Hindus of
comments: Love Nyepi. Even the airport is shut down. Just the local wildlife doesn't keep quiet so it's wonderful.  No taxis beeping their horns ü§ó$$it would be nice just to sit and listen to the sounds of nature and not the cities.$$Gutted our naivety means we'll be leaving on 27 April instead of experiencing this unique celebration!$$Justina Aleksaitƒó next on the list for you and Mr. G.....amazing!

message+desc: Explore one of Indonesia‚Äôs indigenous cultures in the stunningly beautiful Baliem Valley  in Papua, home of the Dani Tribe. Watch the exciting Baliem Valley Festival  where opposing tribes hold simulated traditional battles. Regarded by many to be one of the highlights of Papua, here come witness traditional ceremonies, bargain with the local people in traditional markets and taste the Dani Tribe‚Äôs simple cuisine. This is truly an unforgettable journey of culture and nature that you must include in your bucket list. http://indonesia.travel/en/destination/area/baliem-valley  #WonderfulIndonesiaHigh up in the mountains of central Papua at an altitude of 1,600 meters above sea level, hemmed in by steep green mountain walls, lies the stunningly beautiful Baliem Valley, home of the Dani tribe. Baliem valley is 72 km long, and 15-31 km wide in places. It is cut by the Baliem River, which has i...

message+desc: Starting from last week, Seoul Plaza, Cheonggye Plaza, and Gwanghwamun Square were designated NON-SMOKING areas. Do you think this policy is a good thing or a bad thing?^^;;In an effort to reduce the effects of second-hand smoke, the city of Seoul has passed legislation that bans smoking in 3 major downtown areas. message+desc:
Get a tax refund on your hotel stay! 
Find out how here: http://bit.ly/1qf5hQm
comments:
It says, "...applicable to international visitors who stay in a certified hotel for a total of more than two nights, but less than 30. In order to receive the tax refund, eligible recipients should be scheduled to leave Korea within 3 months from their check-out date." 
It also says, "Only foreign tourists who do not hold a work-related visa or who are staying for more than 6 months are eligible for the Hotel Tax Refund." So this means that 1) we must stay in Korea for more than 6 months, 2) during this period hotel stay in certified hotel must be more than 2 nights but less than 30 nights, and 3) we must leave Korea within 3 months after the hotel check out date. ? Is this correct? Basically most of us regular tourists will not be eligible since we are not likely to stay in Korea for more than 6 months.$$Can we get tax refund if we booked the hotel through the online booking like agoda/hotels.com/booking.com/etc? Or where should we booked the hotel to get the tax refund? Thank you.$$Where can I find it out the certified hotel list?$$Can we pick up the documentation we need from the duty free zone in Incheon Airport?  Will there be a list of certified hotels?  Crossing my fingers that the two I have booked for our trip qualify!  Thanks!$$Where we can find the certified hotel list?$$Stay in korea over 6mths for travel without work?$$Is this at any hotel in Korea?$$staying for 2 nights cannot fax refund??that means stays for at least 3nights in certified hotel right?$$very comfortable and warm!!$$Do you have a full list of certified hotels for reference.. Was it extend to include budget hotels or guesthouse/ motel?$$I assume hotels not in the list do not have tax refund.$$Thanks for yr fast reply :)$$Is the Tax Refund is applicable for tourist who come in group as in follow the tour? if we follow the tour, our stay will be less than 6 months..$$Low Edmund please read . thanks$$Do u have a list of certified hotels participating in this scheme?$$The Tax Refund Eligibilty, on point number one says it is only for visitors saying MORE than 6 months. Is this correct?$$I shall have a look Í∞êÏÇ¨Ìï©ÎãàÎã§

message+desc:
This viral photo of the newly-painted houses on a hill in Barangay Balili, La Trinidad Benguet will be unveiled tomorrow by outgoing Tourism Secretary Mon Jimenez who served as the inspiration of the project. #itsmorefuninthePhilippines

http://www.wheninmanila.com/look-benguet-puts-color-on-houses-has-rio-de-janeiro-feel/
comments: I had commented earlier, however, I just want to show you a photo similar to this one you have done to this place in La Trinidad. It was indeed, a brilliant idea. Bright colors has transformed the city significantly. The intense color of the houses made the once dull scenery an attractive one. It makes the people come back again to see our beautiful city of Pines. Hopefully, other places in Baguio will have some if not total transformation too. Whoever had the idea of this transformation, I will say good job!!!$$parang Cinque Terre or Como lang.. :) good job! i hope the surroundings are well maintained as well then that can be a picturesque spot..$$I haven't seen this bit for quite a while so I don't know how the old place looks like. This  is a real face lift, very clever idea, and a fantastic view as you enter that bend from the bell church. It looks like Portugal, a little bit of Italy?..$$I HAVE A BIG SUGGESTION: If you can be able to put up a 3D TExT near NAIA, saying WELCOME TO THE PHILIPPINES... those text are not visible in any side but the pillars are scattered everywhere, The people who arrived who are on the plane can see the text when the plane landed but not on land, those pillars will slowly merge and create the word upon taxi. if you know what I mean.$$We're planning to go on vacation, this June, and we're thinking of what  nice place to go to, thanks for this picture, gives me an idea!$$Thanks, Davies Paints, Philippines for donating all the paint!$$Hoping all the tourism hotspots in the country follow a particular Philippine motif...$$So picturesque! Kudos to this great improvement. I hope the townspeople will continue to foster this community. Great job!$$Brilliant .... There should be many, many more like that ....$$Wow I hope it is really how it looks now.way back it was far from the picture.good job. Make it more inviting .$$Bianca Eumi Jean friendssss! Eto pa!! message+desc: Puso (pu-so) is rice wrapped and steamed in woven coconut leaves. Originally from Cebu, this traditional way of serving rice makes it a convenient and perfect partner for barbecue, lechon or other streetside food. Not to be confused with the other word "puso" or heart, although rice IS close to every Pinoy's heart. Photo taken from outoftownblog.com

Guard changing ceremony at Gyeongbokgung >>> http://bit.ly/UMtDzS

The people who guarded the gate of the palace were called "Sumungun(Gatekeepers)," and their leader was Sumunjang. Sumunjang(the chief gatekeeper) in the Joseon Dynasty lead the guards of the main gates of Joseon's capital, as well as the gates of Joseon Royal palaces. 

This photo was sent to us by Edith R. Gonzales

message+desc:
Nagasaki Lantern Festival is being held at Chinatown in Nagasaki City till Feb. 14th. Nagasaki is located at the western edge of Kyushu and it has made this city international as the center site of the trade with other countries since 15th century. 
 During the festival, you can enjoy about 15,000 colorful lanterns illuminating the city as well as the events as traditional Chinese dancing or parades. Why don‚Äôt you go and feel the fantastic atmosphere?
¬©Nagasaki Kanko Remei

Destination guide:
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/nagasaki/teramachi.html

That's awesome$$Amazing city! I loved it when I was there. During the festival it must be so great!

Isla de Gigantes a.k.a. the Gigantes group of Islands are found at the northeast and least-visited part of Iloilo. They say the islands were once inhabited by giants, after people discovered coffins measuring up to  8-feet long! Today visitors get to enjoy quiet and protected beaches, caves & lagoons. 

Photo by Denise Tolentino

message+desc:
Where is it?
Lake Balinsasayao, Negros Oriental

What is it?
Lake Balinsasayao is a crater lake that's the result of decades of rain. It rests on the Cuernos de Negros mountain range 918 meters above sea level. Trekking up the mountain offers a spectacular view of the lakes, and of the neighboring islands of Cebu, Bohol and Siquijor.

Fun Fact:
Lake Balinsasayao is actually made up of twin lakes that are separated by a thin ridge. You can kayak on these lakes, and even have a picnic next to them.
comments: Once in a lifetime experience!$$It's Really More Fun in the Philippines$$https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=1117254769951&set=a.1117251169861.2020676.1184446956&type=3&theater$$Pano ang pagpunta dyn? I want to visit that place soon.

message+desc:
Fatehpur Sikri (the City of Victory), built during the reign of Emperor Akbar in the second half of the 16th century, was the capital of the Mughal Empire between 1571 and 1585. The palace complex, comprising monuments, and temples, is constructed in a uniform architectural style and includes the Jama Masjid, one of the largest mosques in India. 

This ancient fortified city, located 40km west of #Agra, is a World Heritage Site and an excellent specimen of Mughal architecture in India.
comments: I visited Fatehpur Sikri, an excellent creation.Beautiful place.$$Me too. Been there couple times. Nice.$$TOTALY LOVED THIS PLACE

message+desc:
Where is it?
The Malaca√±ang Palace, Manila

What is it?
Before it became the Presidential Palace, Malaca√±ang Palace was a temporary summer home for Spanish governors and American civil governors.

Fun Fact:
There are several theories as to how the palace got its name. The official story from the 1930s says the name comes from a Filipino phrase which means "there is a nobleman here," because it was originally the home of a wealthy Spanish merchant."

Photo by the Tourism Department of the Philippines.
comments: Not inspiring. Rather embarrassing looking at the pollution and weather stains. You could at least show the front of Malaca√±ang.$$Actually I think it was the official residence of the Captain Generals, not their summer home.

message+desc:
Where is it? 
CCP, Manila

What is it? 
The Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) is the premiere showcase of the arts in the country. Founded in 1969 under the Marcos regime, it still continues to hold the most celebrated and award-winning plays from around the world. At night, it's therapeutic to watch the fountain lightshow ‚Äî a colorful oasis by the side of the main road, in the middle of a busy metro.

How to get there: 
Fly into Manila through one of more than 30 international airlines. You can also fly in from any major Philippine city.

Or take a bus from any major city in Luzon.

Or take a boat from any major Philippine port.

Fun Fact: 
In the main lobby of the National Theater, you'll notice three large Capiz-shell chandeliers hanging from the third-floor ceiling. They symbolize the three main geographical divisions of the Philippines ‚Äî Luzon, Visayas and Mindanao.

Photo by/Headline by: 
George Tapan/Donna Dimayuga
comments: I LOVE MY COUNTRY....BLESSED MY HOMELAND FOREVER.$$I remember hanging around here when we lived in Legaspi Towers adjacent to this building$$It is good that you are featuring landmarks that were once forgotten by political differences.... We commend this noble act. After all, we must remember the contributions the center have made to the growth of the country's tourism and culture.$$Those where the good old days... :D$$Very beautiful place

We did not know of any happening events at Quayside Isle, and also the place is quite far from our home and may be a little too quiet for us. I am looking for some place new for us to visit and after reading the website, I'm keen to go there for our Christmas celebration this year. It seems like a secret place hidden in Singapore with gems inside!$$I would like to spend this Christmas at Quayside Isle as it would be an unique experience for my friends and I. We usually hang out in bars or pubs and after so many years, it is time for a change. A different and exotic silent night!

Esther L Chng Joy Yeo$$I didn't know Quayside Isle was that pretty until I have read your blog, it just don't look at Singapore, a perfect mini getaway. The restaurants have food that look so great too, hoping to try it!! This christmas season hoping to get some christmas spirit there too!

message+desc:
Where is it?
El Nido, Palawan

How to Get There:
"Fly from Manila to El Nido.

Or fly from Manila to Puerto Princesa, then take a bus to El Nido."

What is it?
El Nido, Palawan has one of the most diverse and highly protected ecosystems in the country. It is known for its unique flora and fauna, and towering geological limestone formations.

Fun Fact:
El Nido has 50 white sand beaches for you to choose from, and 813 species of fish for you to meet.

Photo by / Headline by:
Miguel Teotico / Rachel Teotico

The rules:
- Opens at midnight or later.
- Start taking when the stall's light is turned on.
- Form 2 queues - one to take (grab), one to pay.

- Don't block the way, or get scolded.

message+desc:
Know anyone who‚Äôs Kapampangan? Here‚Äôs a helpful guide on understanding your friend. Don‚Äôt forget to share this with him/her! 

http://www.positivelyfilipino.com/magazine/10-things-you-need-to-know-about-kapampangansHow best to understand the natives of Pampanga Province.
comments:
I lived and worked in Angeles, San Fernando and Dau near the bus terminal last 2010 working as part of the marketing team of a Makati hotel trying to capture the kapampangan market. This blog has probably captured the true description of this culinary center yet often misunderstood people& province. I only got to taste authentic homegrown kapampangan cooking when I got invited to a wedding in a barrio in Arayat. It was lavish for a barrio wedding with everyone helping in. And all the foods were truly the famous cabalen home cooking I've been hearing of. I specially liked the sweet adobo meat & when they told me it's a dog, I turned my eyes on the duck, prawn and pork menus.haha. We dipped in the cold springs of Mt.Arayat. For me, that wedding was the focal point of my Pampanga sojourn.$$Yes, it is very true that
"Kapampangans are deeply religious which, of course, is not the same as spiritual. Their fetish for anitos (spirit idols) has morphed into an excessive, almost irrational, devotion to anything associated with their colonizers‚Äô religion. Kapampangans have found their new idols on which to lavish their affections: the church temple for which they‚Äôd spend any amount to build, rebuild and renovate; the retablos and santos (altars and icons) which they over-decorate, over-dress, and over-process; and of course their priests whom they over-revere to the point of electing one as governor."

The many details enumerated above made Bro Eli Soriano, who is not a Kapampangan, stay in this province and dare to focus his efforts to preach the Biblical Gospel of Christ, even if the teachings of our Lord and Saviour that he trumpets are often the exact opposite to the idolatrous Catholic teachings given to the local populace.

The ADD Convention Center was later built in Apalit to continue the banner television and radio program named Ang Dating Daan, and with the mercy and grace of God, thousands of Kapampangans have left the catholic faith and joined the 100% Bible-based Church of God.
...$$All said is true that is the real kapampangan for my family originated in apallit but grew up in tarlac$$My Grandparents raised all their 8 kids at the foothills of Mount Arayat and my cousins and I would spend our summers here - Arayat Represent!!! :D$$Jaa: Was about to tag on this but nakauna naman diay ka lol. Ahaha$$Nicole don't you think this is all true?$$kabalen..my mother is kapampangan..ofcourse it's started w/ mu lola...I love the warmth of the family ng mga kapampangan pride.I think we're from Lubao at Apalit...$$Tena mangan! was my favorite when I was growing up on visits to my Indangs and Tatangs in San Mathias...those were cherish memories till I die.

message+desc:
Haridwar - One of the holiest sites in India and venue of the Kumbh Mela

Haridwar, situated on the right bank of the holy Ganga, is regarded among the seven sacred cities of India. Legend has it that this was one of the four sites across India where a drop of Amrit, carried by Garuda, the celestial fell.

It is therefore one of the four venues where the Kumbh Mela ‚Äì said to the largest congregation of humanity anywhere in the world ‚Äì is held once every 12 years. Haridwar is also the place where the river Ganga enters the Indo-Gangetic plains for the first time. Haridwar is also home to several ashrams which specialize in teaching meditation and yoga. 

- See more at: http://www.incredibleindia.org/travel/destination/haridwar
comments: https://www.facebook.com/sqrpix/photos/a.395540340546338.1073741828.208387742594933/633705000063203/?type=1&theater$$How to plan your vacation to India - @incredibleindia - http://tinyurl.com/phlhhef

message+desc:
How about a steamy bowl of Kongnamul gukbap (ÏΩ©ÎÇòÎ¨ºÍµ≠Î∞•; Bean Sprouts and Rice Soup) for today? 

Detailed recipes for kongnamul are seen in 1910, and tradition records that it first originated in Jeonju. The traditional Jeonju kongnamul gukbap is made by boiling rice and kongnamul in a Tukbaeki (unglazed earthen pot) with lots of seasonings. Nakji jeotgal (salted and fermented octopus) and kimchi are common side dishes.

message+desc:
Though colder weather is around the corner, Japan has a number of dishes that are at their best during the wintery months ahead. ‚ÄúNabe-ryori‚Äù or ‚ÄúNabe‚Äù, otherwise known as Japanese hot pot, is an assortment of ingredients such as meat, vegetables, or seafood, are all stewed together slowly in a giant bowl. Sitting around the hot pot in good company; eating together with friends and family. These are some of the great seasonal pleasures of Japan. 
Try ordering a ‚ÄúNabe‚Äù during your visit. You‚Äôre sure to feel right at home!
Related Information:
http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/attractions/dining/food/jfood_02.html 
http://www.rdpc.or.jp/kyoudoryouri100/ryouri/pdf/japan%27stastysecrets.pdfhttp://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/attractions/dining/food/jfood_02.html

message+desc:
Where is it?
Coron, Palawan

How to Get There:
Fly from Manila to Busuanga, then transfer to a van bound for Coron.

What is it?
The wrecks of a World War II Japanese supply fleet are the main attraction for most divers in Coron. The ships have long since become part of the surrounding marine habitat. They're even home to scores of corals and fish.

Fun Fact:
The ten wreck sites have something for everyone's tastes. They were even listed in Forbes Traveler Magazine's "Top 10 Best Dive Sites in the World."

Photo by / Headline by:
Adrien Uichico / Magnus Ahmad

message+desc:
#Jeongwol #Daeboreum refers to the first full moon of the #LunarNewYear, which falls on the 15th day of the lunar calendar. And #DidYouKnow, this first full moon is known to be the largest and roundest of all the moons in the year! In 2016, this day falls on February 22 of the Gregorian calendar. Does your country have a similar celebration on this day? :D

Learn more on Daeboreum #customs ‚òû  bit.ly/1PyPwBa
comments: In Indonesia, only Chinese Indonesian celebrate the 15th day of the lunar new year. We called it 'cap go meh' (literary means the eve of 15th) .  People will go to the temple for praying on that day. There will also be lion dance and / or dragon dance performances on that day.$$Yes! In Singapore we Chinese celebrate the 15th day of the Lunar New Year with ancestral prayers. It's also the Chinese Valentine Day.$$Yes , We Indians celebrate holi on #fullmoon  day this 22nd. Holi is festival of colours.$$Oh i'll make sure that i won't missed to see the #fullmoon this 22nd (Y)

message+desc:
WIN WIN WIN:

Simply tell us what attracts you to Malaysia and stand a chance to win hotel stay, courtesy of Prince Hotel & Residence Kuala Lumpur.

p/s: Being creative in your words has higher chances of being the chosen winner.  :P

Rules:
- Contest Ends on 31st May 2013, Friday.
- Contest is only eligible for residents residing in Singapore.
- Tourism Malaysia, Singapore office reserves the right at our discretion to decide on the winner and amend the terms of this contest.
comments:
Thank you for taking part in this contest. We are in the midst of deciding. We shall be announcing the winner soon.   :)$$For me....only one word comes to mind....FOOD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!$$Wow! That is simply good and wonderful news. Now I can utilize it for my month end trip to run at Standarard Chartered Marathon in KL!   Whoopee!! Thanks a million!$$JB for weekend grocery shopping & good value dinner. Move a little more Melaka, place for heritage trail & night market jonker street. specialty food of satay, luk luk steamboat & my favorite of cheesy. steamboat. Kuala Lumpur great city for shopping. Great shopping malls at Bukit.Bintang & great food street like Alor. Genting great place for Young & Old. A get away place from the hot weather. Great mountain, white beaches, different tribes are just the many reasons for East Malaysia.  A great close destination, our neighbour, Malaysia Truly Asia.....$$Malaysia offers one of the most ideal destination for travel. Malaysia offers a varied range of activities from the highlands of Cameron Highlands and the lush greenery of the oldest rainforest to the white sandy beaches. There is always that city limelights that beckons you for a night out of fun or self indulgence. The ethnic diversity is shared in the myriad colours in traditional wear, the culinary delight that is shared by all and the warmth welcoming hospitality greeted you as you travel around Malaysia . From the Portugese settlers in Melaka to the unique Baba culture to the 3 main ethnic group, there is always an experience and a sweet memory to savior.$$Truly Malaysia with lots of friendly faces, nice local delights and free from war. Malaysia has lots of facinating places which could reduce our stress life in Singapore$$I love to travel to KL and its outskirts.   It offers both new modern shopping centres of mega scales like One Utama or Midvalley to Hypermarkets like Tesco to wholesale like Kenaga etc and yet you can find diversity in old shops in many areas to pasar malam in different vicinity and the open markets like in Jalan Ara.  Simply love the mood when I can go slow or at a fast pace,  the crowd yet you don't find it claustrophobic , the buzz and lively atmosphere you may find at Pavillion dining boulevard close to midnight and above all I felt relaxed each time I am there.  

The main draw for me is the food scene and you are spoilt for choices.  Each time I am there I never fail to make new discoveries and I am so often thrilled by the gem of the new found place and the smacking good food it offers.  

I indulged in the many nice hotels that abounds in KL and I am a frequent customer of Prince Hotel, my favorite accommodation in KL for its image, service, accessibility and proximity to the shopping belts and a short walk away from the midnight movie that I catch at the Pavillion.   

Taxis have been my favorite mode of transportation, so easily available and I always got a wealth of information on places to drink and dine and places of interest.

Truly it's a haven for tourist like me!$$Warm Malaysian Hospitality,authentic local delights,culture and traditions,homestay,indulge in various village pastimes,agro visits delights of rural living$$I love foremost the exotic beaches at Redang, green lushful mountains in Kedah the hilly stations. Shopping in KLCC is awesome and can never be enough. Foods are finger licking and many Halal certified restaurant. Last but not least, Malaysians are friendly by nature and approachable.$$1st & foremost love to go holiday to Malaysia because of the foods that really appeal to my appetite. Stay in their exclusive 5 star hotel & visit their interesting attractions place that sure brings me & family to go holiday to Malaysia. We plan to go holiday to Kelantan to visit my long penpal when I get to know her I was in my teens.$$From the crystal blue waters around the famed island of Sipadan, where divers are surrounded by turtles, schools of jacks and the chance to dive around the only island that is not connected to any continent. To the idyllic island of Langkawi where one can relax under a beach umbrella at Pantai Cenang idling away your time.

Stopping over in Malacca for the foodie lover and moving on to Kuala Lumpur to indulge more in local food and shopping. To burn away all that excess calories, why not opt being 'Tarzan or Jane' for a day and traverse between tree to tree at SkyTrek Adventure Park? If climbing is not your cup of tea, perhaps exploring Mulu caves in Sarawak may bring you back to nature. 

For the adrenaline junkie, Sepang tracks await you and if you do not have a car to speed your way through the tracks, how about Go-karting instead?

So with that many options available and many more places to explore just a doorstep away, how can Malaysia not attract me over?$$Malaysis is the one of the most pleasant, hassle-free countries to visit in 
S.E.A. Its buoyant and wealthy culture based on a vibrant fusion of Malay, Chinese and Indian .
Malaysia has a wide range of tourist attraction. This include the hi-tech city Kuala Lumpur to the tropical island if Langkawi. Malaysia has the potential of catering to tourist of every hue and truly lives up to its tag line of Malaysia truly Asia.$$The diversity of the unique cultural traditions, the well-deserved reputation of food heaven in South East Asia and the friendliness of the people there are simply so welcoming.  It is like a home away from home. A perfect place for a getaway, to rest and to relax. For this, i am truly in love with Malaysia.$$Have u seen Rafflesia in Sabah ? its so attractive and cannot move your eyes aways from it. i saw six.                                                                      
Have u seen Lake Kenyir at Trengannu ? you have to be on boat 2 days 2 nights to able to call it a tour !                                                                
Have u been to Night Dive in Redang ? The purple cushion starfish is my love of my life...                                                                                         
Have u experience fireworks for 7 long nights in front of your balcony ? we witness in A'Farmosa Malacca.                                                                                   
Have u enjoy the whole beach by yourself and built the sand castle ? we catches fish/crab/prawn with a PAIL in Tg Sutera Johor. 
Have u try Kee Ngiah kueh in Penang ? Buah Long Long drink in Penang ? Kueh Kak in Penang ? Penang is more than char kuey teow !

Sejak dulu, Kepulauan Derawan telah menjadi salah satu habitat alami bagi penyu hijau; mulai dari mencari makan, melakukan perkawinan, beristirahat, hingga bertelur. Hal ini karena Kepulauan Derawan memiliki kekayaan terumbu karang dan alga; tempat yang tepat bagi penyu mencari makanan. Sayangnya, dari tahun ke tahun jumlah penyu hijau yang singgah dan menitipkan telurnya di Kepulauan Derawan selalu mengalami penurunan. http://indonesia.travel/attraction/attraction_details/150/penyu-hijau-penjelajah-samudera-yang-terancam-punah-di-kepulauan-derawan

message+desc: Palawan is on a roll! After having been voted for 2 straight years as the "Best Island in the World" by readers of Cond√© Nast Traveler, one of its beaches, El Nido, is named the "Most Beautiful Beach in the World!" #itsmorefuninthePhilippines #VisitPhilippinesAGAINShockingly, Palawan has remained steadily under the radar, and we certainly hope it stays that way. El Nido alone is home to around 50 white sand beaches‚Äîit‚Äôs impossible to choose just one‚Äîall of which are set around dramatic limestone formations and boast the finest and whitest sand you‚Äôll ever see‚Ä¶
comments:
It's good that Palawan is making a lot of buzz this year by making it to the top when it comes to best island and beaches. But too much publicity can lead to unhealthy tourism that may ruin its number one tourist draw, its natural beauty. When people start to notice some place business comes in, hotels, resorts and other tourist infrastructures and sometimes it leads to the destruction of the place. We want the tourists to come but we want to preserve the place as well. Balance is the key to a healthy and sustainable tourism industry.$$The most beautiful island in the world and my second home. El Nido is amazing but getting busy I would hate to see it turn into another Boracay just full of rich tourists and hotels. Palawan needs conservation too.$$El Nido...truly heaven. Please don't spoil it by promoting too much tourism.$$One of the best days of my life! This was took in Merimegmeg Beach in El Nido last Feb. Zip line adventure and you can walk through the beach after you get to the other island. It's amazing, you should try it! <3$$I just want to share my recent trip to Nagtabon Beach in Puerto Princesa,  Palawan http://www.angelotheexplorer.com/2015/10/nagtabon-beach-beautiful-and-unspoiled.html$$Palawan is the most beautiful island.$$El Nido, Palawan is indeed the last Frontier of the Philippine Island! Truly amazing! :-)$$El Nido in my mind. This was three weeks ago.$$I agree! I hope sustainable tourism is being applied! Especially now that Palawan is getting more and more known in the world.$$My Father was born here in Palawan "Puerto Princesa". I am proud and happy to know that it is called and voted "Best Island In The World". message+desc:
10 Bizarre Things Singaporeans Do That The Rest Of The World Won't Understand

The foreigners may not say it. But things that are normal to us, like being called meinu (pretty) and shuai ge (handsome), are hella weird to them.

Here're 10 confirmations that we're the strangest nationality in our own home.

Follow TheSmartLocal.com for more stories like this!

http://thesmartlocal.com/read/singaporean-culture-quirksTo all our foreign friends out there, here's the cheat sheet on our local culture, habits and lingo that'll make you a true-blue Singaporean. Steady, lah.

message+desc:
Where is it?
Olango Islands, Cebu 

What is it?
This island group is composed of the main Olango Island and its six satellite islets. The site is a wildlife sanctuary that serves as a pit stop for migratory birds that come from as far as China, Japan and Siberia.

Fun Fact:
The seven islands of the Olango group are joined together by a continuous reef. This makes the site a nice diving spot as well.

Photo by / Headline by:
Tourism Department Philippines / Jao Bautista
comments:
Really? Been to NAIA? love the Philippines thou$$Hope the migratory birds do not carry SARS.$$Sandeep Kumar Pandey Kindly refrain from posting spam to avoid being banned from this page. Thank you.$$John Flynn 
Next time we are in Cebu!$$Celyn Milan Please refrain from posting spam here to avoid being banned. Thank you.

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Espa√±a, Manila

What is it like?
University of Sto. Tomas is one of the largest Catholic universities in the world. It's also the Philippines‚Äôs oldest. Founded on April 28, 1611, the university boasts providing more than 400 years of quality education in the Philippines.

How to get there: 
Fly into Manila through one of more than 30 international airlines. You can also fly in from any major Philippine city.

Or take a bus from any major city in Luzon.

Or take a boat from any major Philippine port.

Fun Fact: 
The university has its share of remarkable alumni, including four Philippine presidents: Manuel Quezon, Sergio Osme√±a, Jose Laurel, and Diosdado Macapagal.

Photo by/Headline by: 
George Tapan/Brandon Dollente

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Batanes, Luzon

How to get there: 
Fly into Batanes from Manila, Cagayan or Ilocos Norte.

What is it like? 
Biking is the ideal way to get a feel for Batanes, with its rolling hills and friendly locals. Around here, it's all about the experience of getting lost.

Fun Fact: 
Batanes is the smallest province in the Philippines, both in terms of population and land area.

You think being stuck in the 9-6 grind is difficult, but rarely think about this group of people who work while you're asleep to care for your loved ones like their own.

Our journalists spoke to, among many people, a 19 year-old who gave up law school for nursing. Here's why she did it.

message+desc:
Where is it?
Palawan, Puerto Princesa

What is it?
The series of protruding limestone formations unique to Palawan make the province home to lakes as well. These lakes are formed when water is trapped in the spaces in between the limestone cliffs. 

Fun Fact:
A Palawan getaway wouldn‚Äôt be complete without limestone cliff diving. The otherworldly rock formations make a picturesque backdrop for jumpshot-off-the-cliff photos.

Photo by / Headline by:
George Tapan / Jao Bautista

message+desc:
‚ÄúKAERI-BANA‚Äù literally means returned flower. It is also called as forgotten flowers.

In the beginning of winter, this phenomenon occurs. The weather is cool in the morning and evening, warm in daytime. Because of this warm climate, some flowers mistakenly bloom again.

Who is lucky enough to see the spring flowers in the beginning of winter?!

Photo from the top to the clockwise direction, plum, azalea and cherry blossom.

More Information:
Seasonal Rhythm: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/indepth/seasonal/
Various Flowers: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/attractions/rest/hana/hana_p4.html
comments: So nice to have a name for this. One of the trees in my garden is doing it

message+desc: Explore the pristine nature of Bali at Menjangan Island, West Bali National Park
comments: the last week i've been there... there a beautiful place that i ever knows...amazed.$$...the pristine nature of Bali ! Pulau Menjangan, a 175-hectare sanctuary island, a part of West Bali National Park, off the northwest coast at the western entrance of Teluk Terima, received its name from the wild java deer that graze on its open savannahs. This island boasts of what is believed to be Bali oldest temple, Pura Gili Kencana, which dates from the Majapahit period.

message+desc: The Apo Reef National Marine Park is the second-largest contiguous coral system in the world. That means it's the perfect place to see turtles, sharks, manta rays, sting rays, sea hawks and colorful tropical fish. No resorts here so bring your camping gear for a cool adventure! Photo taken from dugongdivecenter.com

message+desc:
*Important Update*
We have been informed by MOE that the school actually requires approval from MOE before visiting and we understood the "enter at your own risk" sign wrongly. It is that way as it is meant to be open for residents nearby to jog along the driveways and also to provide a shortcut for nearby residents to reach the bus-stop along Braddel Road. Any un-approved visit from MOE by any public would be seen as trespassing and will be prosecuted by Police.

It is also now being guarded by security guards 24 hours daily.
Please do not visit this area anymore or try to enter.

*End of update*
Original post is as follows below.
--------------

The former Braddell-Westlake Secondary School has been abandoned since 2005, and as with abandoned places, eerie vibes here are at an all-time high.  The amazing thing about this place? Unlike most abandoned places, the gates here are opened with the disclaimer "Enter at your own risk" instead of "Trespassers will be prosecuted." Yay!

Graffitied walls, shattered windows and dusty floors are a dead giveaway on this place‚Äôs inhabitants. Or lack thereof. One more desolated location to check off your photography bucket list!

Directions: Take a train to Braddell MRT, then walk towards blk 209 and follow the sheltered walkway.

Follow TheSmartLocal.com for more such videos!
Model: Lydia Hunter

Also read:

http://thesmartlocal.com/read/abandoned-places
http://thesmartlocal.com/read/never-seen-before-sg

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Pasay, Metro Manila

What is it like? 
On the first day of September, the Filipino Christmas season unofficially begins. Christmas trees and star-shaped lanterns start to fill the streets. Schools start to put together plays about the birth of Jesus Christ. Christmas remixes of the year's most popular songs start to play on the radio. The whole country is transformed for a solid four months. It's the longest Christmas celebration in the world. And it also has a good claim to being the happiest. 

How to get there: 
Fly into Manila through one of more than 30 international airlines. You can also fly in from any major Philippine city.

Or take a bus from any major city in Luzon.

Or take a boat from any major Philippine port.

Fun Fact: 
Adults or children form groups and visit homes at night to sing carols. When given change, young carolers typically sing a thank-you song in Filipino that goes, "Thank you, thank you, you're so kind, thank you!" When given change money, the song changes to, "Thank you, thank you, you're so stingy, thank you!"

Photo by/Headline by: 
Tourism Department Philippines/Tin Sanchez
comments: Philippines , here we come.

message+desc:
Where is it?
Banaue, Ifugao

How to Get There:
Take a bus bound for Banaue from Sampaloc. 

Or take a bus bound for Baguio from Cubao or Pasay, then transfer to a bus bound for Banaue.

What is it?
The Banaue Rice Terraces are 2,000 year old terraces that were carved into the mountain by the Ifugao people. 

Fun Fact:
The terraces were built mostly by hand. 

Photo by / Headline by:
George Tapan / Rachel Teotico
comments: Me too...aww inspiring$$Pls check the grammar and research..about  the ethnic / tribal name of the people from Ifugao...u talk about the Philippines..be sure its factual and complete...$$If you take a Baguio bound bus first and transfer to another bus for Banaue, u are just doubling the travel time and fare.

Where is it?
Panglao Island, Bohol

What is it?
Panglao Island has a white sand beach for every kind of traveler ‚Äî from the restaurant-dotted strip of Alona Beach to peaceful Dumaluan Beach to seashell-rich Doljo Beach.

Fun Fact:
It was on this day in 1565 that Bohol was founded, when Spanish explorer Miguel Legazpi came to the island-province looking for spices and gold.

Photo by / Headline by:
George Tapan  / Magnus Ahmad

10 Ph·ªüs in Singapore That Are Un-Ph·ªü-gettable 

If you've craving a good bowl of pho, this is the only list you need.

Bohol, Visayas.

Tarsiers measure three to six inches in height, making them one of the smallest primates in the world. This also makes them difficult to spot!

The tarsier can turn its head 180 degrees in both directions.

message+desc:
Situated in the idyllic town of Khao Yai is Thailand's LARGEST flower garden!

Spanning over 160,000 square metres and featuring over 30 species of flowers in winter alone, The Bloom is just a 3 hour drive away from Bangkok. Best part is that the flowers here bloom all year round so you can be assured of beautiful floral backdrops no matter what time of the year it is. What's more, there's even a cafe there that you can take a break at when your feet get tired.

Find out more about The Bloom and Khao Yai here: http://thesmartlocal.com/read/khao-yai 

Never want to miss a post by us again?
Like TheSmartLocal.com and set Notifications to "All On"

message+desc:
Crystal clear water, white sandy beaches, and natural hot springs!

Shikinejima Island is one of Izu Islands on Pacific Ocean, and it‚Äôs hard to believe this little slice of paradise is a few hours from the capital of Tokyo!
Little known to travelers to Japan, Shikinejima Island‚Äôs pristine shores makes it an ideal spot for snorkeling, scuba diving, and all-around fun and leisure.
 
Access: Three hours from Tokyo Takeshiba Terminal by high-speed jet ferry 
Izu Islands: http://www.jnto.go.jp/eng/location/regional/tokyo/izusititou.html
Photo courtesy: Shikinejima Tourist Office

message+desc:
One of the most surreal thing I've done in the ocean is to swim my way across the sea looking at the centuries old niches and tombs sunk on the ocean floor a century and a half years ago. You are looking at the face of Jesus and a tomb cross underneath the ocean. The once resting place of the dead is now ironically teeming with ocean life. Oh the cycle of life on earth is awesome.

Words and Photo by @carloenriquez21
comments:
I've been in Camiguin Island. You can feel the mysterious aura of the island.$$I've been in Camiguin Island 2013. Ang sarap sumakay ng ferry from cagayan de oro to Camiguin. What a beautiful place...$$That's not Jesus that's Mohammed$$How would you know that it is the face of Jesus?$$Jesus or not, looks like he's holding his breath$$Kerrie Saunders John Saunders Johnie Saunders Tara Saunders can we go on trip here!$$We weren't able to see this on our snorkeling Yve Marie Ann Lucero Espie Luyun Bernardo$$Nobody can see the real  face of Jesus ( Isa) (aws)...
Before qiyamaat...!

message+desc:
Sabah: Take a journey back into the colonial days of British North Borneo on board the North Borneo Railway. Experience Tiffin-styled lunch that serves a blend of colonial and Continental cuisine. 

Enjoy the unique sights and sound of local villages paddy fields, mangrove jungle and pristine coastal beaches as you while away a leisurely day in comfort. Featuring the mid-century British "Vulcan" Steam engine, the North Borneo Railway is the last of a fleet of locomotives that have plied the tracks through Borneo since the 1900s.
comments: Yes I experienced this in 2004. At one stop almost Kena leave behind by the train. Luckily the staff saw us running towards the train. Haha. Memorable.$$The Briyani was especially good :-)$$I used to carry my lunch to school with a tiffin like that (perhaps less polished) while growing up in Rangoon, Burma.$$I thought this had stopped running - glad to see it's still going!

message+desc:
Terletak di Teluk Manado, sebelah utara Pulau Sulawesi, Indonesia, Bunaken memiliki luas 8,08 km¬≤. Berada di segitiga terumbu karang membuat taman laut ini menjadi habitat bagi 390 spesies terumbu karang serta ikan, reptile, maupun mamalia laut lainnya. Didirikan pada 1991, 97% dari taman nasional ini merupakan habitat laut, sementara 3% sisanya merupakan daratan, yang meliputi lima pulau: Bunaken, Manado Tua, Mantehage, Naen, dan Siladen. http://ow.ly/S0FtR

#WonderfulIndonesia #PesonaIndonesia

message+desc:
Once a year in Jindo, Jeollanam-do Province, the seas mysteriously part and visitors can walk through the sea from the mainland to a nearby island. This phenomenon is caused due to the difference in high tides and low tides, which creates a 2.8-kilometer-long road measuring 40 to 60 meters in width. 

Jindo Miracle Sea Festival is slated to be held from April 25 to 28 in the Gogun-myeon area of Jindo-gun, Jeollanam-do Province. What is your impression of this ‚Äòmiracle sea‚Äô? ‚Üí http://bit.ly/11MoG0d
comments:
i really recommend this festival...it's really amazing and the story behind it is also fascinating.$$Three times a year, Korean people celebrate the Sea Parting festival or as they call it the Miracle of Moses due to a real splitting of the sea and the appearence of a long sea passage connecting them to the Jindo Island, in the three months of March, May, and August.
the story of the Prophet Moses in the Holy Qur'an and says:

So we revealed to Moses, "Strike the sea with your staff." And it split in two, each part like a towering cliff. And We brought the others right up to it. We rescued Moses and all those who were with him. Then We drowned the rest. There is certainly a Sign in that yet most of them are not believers. Truly your Lord is the Almighty, the Most Merciful.
$$Omo! This is really magnificent! The first kind of festival that I've known which you will cross the sea! (Y)$$Cant happend on November...??? I will there around November...?$$God's creature so awesome,great and amazing!$$I've been there kakak....the place is amazing.....$$Deborah Chua come to visit korea$$Around how long does it stay parted? Is it parted for a day or something? Sounds really awesome!$$Cool. Wish i can be there$$some people say it's like the parting of the Red Sea when the people of Israel left Egypt$$long time i have a dream to reachd there,hopefully one fine day!!$$Really amaziiiing wish I was in the crowd :p$$Ewelina TaheriMilad Heydari u guys should check it out$$Like what Moses did - parting the sea. In this case, it's low tide.

message+desc:
Who wouldn't enjoy cruising on a placid river with abundant food to feast on and jolly kids seranading you along the way? That's the Loboc River Cruise offering and something you shouldn't miss when you #VisitPhilippines.

üì∑: Jeremy Jauncey http://instagram.com/jeremyjauncey

#itsmorefuninthePhilippines üáµüá≠üòäThis is the Loboc River in Bohol, Philippines and the floating cottage that you see lets you cruise the river while having lunch in it. 

During our trip to the Philippines, the Beautiful Destinations team, composed of my brother Tom, Jacob, Sam, James, myself, and our friends from the Tourism Department, had the whole river to ourselves except for some amazing local little girls on the river bank who sang and danced as we floated by üòäüáµüá≠üå¥‚òÄÔ∏è.

In case you haven't seen how vast the forest is, you can see the video of my brother's drone shot via http://instagram.com/jeremyjauncey. üòâüôèüèª

message+desc:
Where is it? 
Baclayon Port, Bohol

What is it like? 
Baclayon is a sleepy, peaceful seaside town‚Äîand one of the oldest communities around, as it was established by two Spanish Jesuits in the 16th century. The architecture is just as breathtaking as the sunsets.

Fun Fact: 
Baclayon is home to the oldest stone church in the Philippines, which was built in 1595.

Photo by/Author: 
Meggy De Guzman/Meggy De Guzman

message+desc:
Dog lovers rejoice! Amid all the cat cafes in Singapore is a lone Dog cafe that few people know about. This place has been around as a cafe for awhile, but recently pivoted into being a full-on Dog Petting Cafe.

We had an absolute blast playing with the dogs, feeding them and getting them to do tricks! Warning: the dogs are smart. They don't come to you unless you bribe them with snacks, haha.

Note: For the safety of the dogs in the cafe, minimum age for entry is strictly 10 - no exception.

p.s this cafe serves NO FOOD and it's located in Bugis+ so go get a 1 for 1 meal before you come here. Bugis+ is currently having a promo and these are the merchants - http://thesmartlocal.com/read/bugis-1for1-deals

p.p.s Never want to miss a post again?
Like TheSmartLocal.com FB Page > Click on "Liked" and set Notifications to "All On".

We are the Furballs (WTF)
Address, opening hours and more info here:
http://thesmartlocal.com/read/wtf-review

Model: Symone Maria Oei
comments:
Went once out of curiosity and never going again for multiple reasons.

Dogs are very food-motivated. So dont expect any of them to pay you much attention unless you are willing to fork out extra for a pack of treats to bribe them into giving you some affection. (No promise they'll give you much either. Given how often they get to chow down on them.)

Secondly, animals need time to grow accustomed to you. When I visited, a regular stepped in and immediately all the pups darted towards her.üôÅ All the other people there had no choice but to sit in the corner and sorta just watch from afar. Not pleasant. But nothing we could do about it either.

After one experience I figured it'd be much more worthwhile to volunteer at an animal shelter to interact with pups who desperately want and deserve love too. (And will likely much more willingly give you love.)

Having a dog myself, I know how much stress dogs can relieve and how affectionate they can be. Dogs are great. But dont exploit them.
Putting them in an environment like this spoils them to the core and will deteriorate their character in the long run.

Edit: Try visiting Mutts and Mittens instead.‚ò∫Ô∏è$$Basically u need to buy treats in order for the dog to stay by ur side for u to touch and interact... If not u will be just wasting money ($10.90 entrance fee) and time there looking at the dogs walking by... I rather go to my relatives and friends house to interact with their dogs (no treats needed) and relieve stress there...$$I don't like the idea of buying treats from the shop in order to attract the doggies. Too much treats are bad for dogs. And are the treats healthy? Eg, dehydrated treats, home made treats etc?$$Just go visit a dog shelter and donate food to the dogs that really need your love and attention. Crappy cafe that exploits animals sucks$$why support this kind of cafe who use animals to make money? There are many dog shelter whose dogs needed more love and attention. Also imagine these pedigree dogs are like clowns waiting to be stuffed with treats...you think it is healthy to be eating treats all the time?$$YueKit Kwan entrance fee is like $10.90/2hrs ($7.90/hr extra) and if you dont buy treats, the dog wont even let you pet them.
Treats itself aldy cost $3/pack and $9 for 4packs. Even if you go there many times, people who bought the treat will always get the dogs attention. So, buy it or leave it.$$The dogs there are not friendly , i almost got hurt when i trying to pet one , me and my boyfriend just go there waste our time and play some games they provided.... 

Ps: even dog shelters or SPCA dogs are friendly to let you pet........ this is shit.....they shld train the dogs more$$I went there once with my boyfriend, bought 2 packets of treats and the dogs still didn't  give a flying f* about us LOL. They took the treats, moved away when we tried to pet them and walked away once we stop feeding. üòÖ Not worth a visit in our opinion.....$$With or without treats it's
really hard to get the dogs to come to you. Lola is one dog that had bad experiences with strangers who just carry her without basic respect of being gentle. You gotta be some kind of God blessed dog whisperer to really have fun. I wasted my $25 though. The pinch is real.$$Went there once. Yes the dogs mostly give you attention if you have treats, but after awhile when they get sleepy they'll crawl into the first person's lap they see, and they pretty much stay there and snooze till you need to move your numbed legs$$Omg why the hate for this place. These are DOGS. They obviously will be treats motivated. Don't worry abt the dogs being overfed. The owners calculate the packs of treats at the end of the day and feed them accordingly. None of them are overweight despite this cafe being opened for years so yea obviously something is being done right.get the pups to do tricks for their food, they are super cute and smart. 

I go there often and I see people grabbing the tiny pups and forcing them to take selfies w them üôÑ do u think that these pups are going to be v fond of u?? Be gentle with them and naturally some of them will be drawn to u. I personally have no trouble luring one or two dogs to snooze/play w me (ps Lulu is a sweet heart ‚ù§Ô∏è) just be patient and visit more often hahaha. 

WTF if ur reading this, please please please come up w yearly membership price üòÇI would totes buy it ‚úåüèªÔ∏è$$The first and only time I visited, most of the dogs were being hogged by some visitors (sleeping on their laps for almost the entire time I was there). So you just end up looking at them and the few dogs left walking around who will mostly ignore you unless you have treats. Waste of money.$$Bad experience there after just one visit. Went there on my birthday but I was sorely disappointed because the dogs do not come to you unless the staff gives u some treats. Extremely boring. Expect to be sitting around looking at the dogs from afar if u do go. I'd much rather go to the local dog shelters where the dogs welcome anyone, regardless of treats.$$lol Prerna Wangnoo i just read the comments and i think u shld just come and meet my dog instead... i charge u half the entrance fee and don't even need treats my dog will fly to u! HAHAHAHAHAHA üòÇüòÇ$$Leonoura Ang it would be nice if they had like dogs that need a home or like adoption at that cafe$$Joann Chan Belinda Goh Julia Lim is this where you three went?? I recognize the dash that liked ah fang haha$$Remember here Chan Carol ? The dags jitao bo chup u if u dun buy treats and feed them$$Durga Devi, we were just talking about this earlier and they really do have one!!  Shall we??$$Kieran shall we go to Singapore for a .... business idea research trip ?$$Christopher Chin & Khoo Hsien Chun you guys should open something like this. Keith Tang and I will be your loyal visitors üòÜ$$Dinesh Sailan ... Dogs, board games and some nice fruity drinks. How's that sound?$$Sarah, Denise, and Hayyu, we need to pay them a visit again. :D$$Once i go i might not leave Heng Shufang Caris Tan >< dey look so cute omoooo$$How i wish i can bring my bth girls.. 1 is underage, only 4years
